Let me go to what Senator Hill, the then Leader of the Opposition, said in March 1995:

speech.para: This is your choice; this is your program; this is your priority.

That is what he said then. We say exactly the same. This was your choice to bring it on, this was your priority to use government business time and this is your priority. But, having put your rather weak case, you want to run up the white flag. You want to vote on it now. You do not want the issues fully and properly debated.

talk.start.para: —If you think the case is so weak, you would be happy to get rid of it.

—On this particular issue, we have several senators wanting to make a contribution to refute the various accusations made by Senator Vanstone and her colleagues. But, Senator Vanstone, you are not willing to face the music. You are not willing to have what you regard as a serious matter debated in this chamber; you are not willing to have that tested. You are willing to invest everything on what you say is a serious matter—that is, a censure motion; you are willing to say that. But you do not actually want it tested. You do not want senators on this side—and presumably you have also gagged Senator Ian Macdonald, who was on the speaker's list, to prevent him from expressing a point of view. Why is this government running scared on this particular issue?
—We are not running scared. You wasted an hour yesterday on notices of motion.

—Senator Alston refers to us wasting an hour. Let me go to another source, Senator Alston. Let me quote our now esteemed President, someone whom I admire enormously. In terms of the Baume motion and taking up government time, what did she say? She said of Senator Evans, `He brought in a censure of one of our senators; he will wear the consequences for having done that.' I am not making any threats; I am merely quoting from one of the most esteemed presiding officers this chamber has ever been blessed with who at that time was acting in another role as chief whip.

speech.para: What this apparently is about is that the moment they come in here to gag the debate basically they are saying: this is a political stunt; this is just a political vengeance thing. If anyone would have summed it up—and I am sure that he will read the transcripts in New York—it would have been Senator Michael Baume. What did he say about the 1995 censure, which was not gagged, compared with Senator Vanstone's 1998 one? He said that it should not be a political stunt or some kind of political `get square'; it must rest on principle. If it is going to rest on principle, let us debate the principles.

Instead, Senator Alston comes in here and not only makes a few accusations but does not have the courage to have anyone respond to him; he moves a gag so that no-one can reply to the gutless Senator Alston. Why is that so, Mr Acting Deputy President?

talk.start.para: —Order! I would ask you to withdraw that remark.

—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will withdraw `gutless' and I will replace it with a minister who totally lacks courage, who comes into this chamber and attacks Senator Bolkus—but refuses to have anyone else respond. And, in moving that motion, he cannot even go to precedence in terms of an attack on an opposition senator. The whole move by this government on this issue has been botched from start to finish.

speech.para: The tactics finally got right on Monday. Their normal tactic on these things is to come in on a Thursday, pre-plan it but not notify us and ambush us with a censure motion after question time, knowing that if it runs its full course the whole of general business will be expunged. They did that some weeks into the previous session with Senator Sherry: they ambushed after question time. They even ambushed the noting of answers to questions—a historical precedent that I hope will never be repeated in this chamber because it grossly embarrassed the President of this place. But then they come in on general business day by way of ambush, knowing that it is not going to cost them any time.

The fact is that, if governments censure opposition senators, they have to pay the price in terms of time. They have to say, `We are willing to give this precedence over all other business and debate it out until its conclusion' if they are serious about a censure motion. But if anything reveals this as a totally grubby, cynical political exercise, it is the fact that they have gagged it. How many gags were moved in this chamber in the life of the Hawke-Keating government? I am not talking about guillotines.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Ray, I think you have had a fair amount of time to put your statement.
—I have unlimited time, once I am given leave on a statement, Mr Acting Deputy President. You know that.
—I thought it was given with the limit being put on it of `a reasonable amount of time'.

—No, there was no limit put on it whatsoever—and, Mr Acting Deputy President, this is going to be full tote odds. So you can sit back and relax and wait to be replaced in an hour's time, or whatever, and you can go back to your room and listen to me speaking there, if you like. But it was leave without a time limit. You concede that? No response.
—Senator Ray, I think leave was given on the understanding that it was going to be a statement, not an epistle; it was not going to go forever. I thought that was the understanding.
—That might have been their understanding; it was not mine. Leave was given.
—It was my understanding as well. If we want to argue that the original question on the notice of motion should be now put, that does take precedence.
—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. Can I apologise and sit down while you are giving a ruling? I was still standing.

—I thought leave was given on the understanding that a statement would be made, but I did not expect a statement to go forever. I took advice on that matter. There is some doubt, in fact, about the motion that Senator Alston moved: that the question be now put. It does take precedence. I think, in the spirit of trying to get on with the debate, Senator Alston gave leave for you to speak. But I think he gave it on the understanding that it would not be endless.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. What I think we are seeing here is yet further evidence of Senator Ray's absolute determination to avoid debating the merits of the issue. The fact is that we moved a gag because you have had three speakers who have not addressed the subject matter of the issue.

interjection.para: The fact is that Senator Ray indicated that he believed that his seeking leave should have precedence over the gag motion. That is certainly not my understanding of standing order 199. But, in the circumstances, when he effectively threatened that he would spend half an hour on a contingent notice of motion, I was prepared to accept that this might be a more expeditious way of dealing with it. What he was saying was, `If you don't give me leave, I will spend half an hour on a contingent notice of motion'; in other words, he was making it clear that he expected that we should give him leave to save time, less than half an hour.

If what he is now saying is that, under guise of seeking to speed up the debate, he is now going to spend an endless amount of time on talking about everything that interests him, then that is a clear abuse of process. It exposes him as someone who is not interested in the forms of the parliament. All these weasel words about what a wonderful person the President is and `I would like to sit down and hear you in silence' should not disguise the fact that what he is doing, if he persists in this conduct, is simply trying to frustrate the processes of the parliament and the government's agenda. I can certainly confirm that Senator Ray made it very clear to us that leave was in lieu of his spending half an hour on a contingent notice of motion.

talk.start.para: —I might be able to assist the chair. I was pointing out, having been given leave, what my rights were and the potential exercise of those rights. I doubt that, even as verbose and garrulous as I can be, I will even get to the half hour that the contingent notice of motion allows for. But it should be made clear to the genius of tactics over there that if he gives leave with that qualification—and he effectively did—that could be the consequence. But I will leave you to make a ruling and then I will get back to the relevant points.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—I did not believe there was a point of order.

—You let Senator Alston speak for five minutes on a point of order. I am speaking to the point of order that Senator Alston so eloquently addressed at length. I wanted to make the point that leave was given by the Senate. What happens to be in Senator Alston's mind at the time, while of interest to us all, is not the crucial point in any ruling you make, Mr Acting Deputy President. Leave was given by the Senate for Senator Ray to make a statement. I gave that leave, as did other senators around the chamber. While it is of interest, if there is anything in Senator Alston's mind or not, I do not think it is relevant to any ruling you make about the decision to grant leave.

—When the Senate gives leave, I believe it does give leave with a reasonable amount of time. It is up to whoever is in the chair at the time as to what they believe is a reasonable amount of time. I will rule that Senator Ray still has the leave of the Senate to continue, but I will listen and when I think the senator has had enough time, I may put the motion.

—We would obviously challenge that ruling, and move dissent to the ruling, but that is for a later time. What I was saying in terms of the proper procedures here in relation to this gag is that the government finally at least got its tactics right. Rather than moving suspension of standing orders and then having a long debate over precedence by way of ambush, they gave notice properly on Monday so that it would come up for debate as government business on Tuesday.

speech.para: I wanted to make the point that it is very important that this procedure be followed in future. The reason why it should be followed and the reason why it will always be resisted like it was last Thursday is that it is an ambush. It is quite clear that the government decided some time Thursday morning to do this, but did not have the courtesy to notify us. The problem for us then in terms of preparation time is that probably only one speaker on our side can speak to it, and that is the person accused. The others do not know about it and cannot prepare. Therefore, the procedure to this point of time of moving it one day and giving people time to prepare for the second day is always going to be the appropriate approach.

If you are looking for precedents you have to go back 17 years to the last time a government tried to gag a censure motion in this place. This was a censure motion moved by Senator Durack. It was to censure an opposition senator. Again the government tried the gag motion.

talk.start.para: —No, the gag was moved by Senator Durack.
—The gag was moved by Senator Durack.
—On an opposition senator.

—On an opposition senator. The gag was moved by Senator Durack then. The Senate was a more benign then; it was defeated. My point to the Senate is that it should be defeated again today because the government has had four speakers on the attack—notably Senator Vanstone, Senator Abetz, Senator Coonan and Senator Alston. Our side has been given only three speakers to respond. That in itself is a manifestly unfair use of the gag.

speech.para: To go back to the President's previous statement, there will be knock-on consequences of that in this chamber, because you are actually using a device to prevent at least equal numbers in this place speaking on the motion. We certainly had Senator Quirke and Senator Cooney who wanted to address different aspects of it. Senator Alston can say what he likes about irrelevancies, but he can be assured that one of our next speakers, Senator Cooney, would have gone right to the heart of matter.

The only precedent we have for gagging a censure motion against an opposition member—not the traditional ones—goes back 17 years and that was defeated in this chamber. The question comes up: why won't this government, having given notice of a motion in government business time, actually debate the resolution out? Why won't they give the opposition at least equal time to debate the motion? The only conclusion that we can draw on this matter is that they do not want to face the counter-attack; they do not want to face up.

talk.start.para: —Counter-attack! Hit me with a feather.

—Hit Senator Vanstone with a feather? Senator Vanstone has made accusations. You do not have the political courage to allow the response to be given. You have to sleaze out of this chamber using the device of a gag—
—Just closing the debate.

—You are not closing the debate at all. Are you going to have a right of response as well? Is that what you are saying? Mr Acting Deputy President, are we also going to have a right of response so that their side gets five speakers?
—Order! Senator Ray, I would remind you that you are making a statement and I would ask you not to be distracted by interjections.

—It was actually a very pertinent one. Let me explain it to you so you understand. I thought Senator Vanstone indicated that that side of politics is not only going to gag this debate; they are going to have another speaker and right of response. Is that what you said?
—No.

—You are not going to have a right of response? You are just going to leave it at four government speakers and three opposition speakers? That is fair according to you? The old stacked jury; that is fair according to you. I thought there was some redemption for Senator Vanstone; never argue that with Senator Alston.

speech.para: What we have here is a government that says censure motions are serious. Clearly, I do not agree with that. I think they have been scattered around like confetti. They have absolutely no relevance. They are carried on political grounds, as happened in the House of Representatives the other day. All this government needs to censure an opposition is to round up two of the other 11 votes. No-one will ever tell me that every one of those will vote on the facts of the case.

Sometimes they might vote for Senator Bolkus because they like him, and not listen to the arguments. Sometimes—and I cannot understand how—they might vote against him in the censure motion because they do not like him. It is an absolute joke. This is not a judicial finding; this is a highly politicised chamber and this is a highly politicised motion in which the views will merely reflect party lines. Can you imagine someone opposite voting in favour of Senator Bolkus or someone on our side voting against him? It probably never happens. Voting on censure motions goes along party lines. For the rest, some will address it on the merits and vote accordingly for or against; others will just vote according to their particular bias at the time.

Today, this government has said that it is willing to censure an opposition senator without other senators being able to express their views. The government is saying, `We're now into this particular issue but we want to bail out.' Why does it want to bail out? It is saying that government business time is more important than censuring Senator Bolkus. To go back to Senator Hill's comments as they apply to this, he said, `This is your choice; this is your program; this is your priority.' To reverse that: the government has made the choice that government legislation is more important than the censure motion on Senator Bolkus. The government is willing to countenance an unfair distribution of speakers and to gag debate when it has had more speakers than the opposition.

To wind up, we have a government too gutless to debate this and too scared to have all the issues put on the table. It is an absolute disgrace that Senator Alston has moved a gag motion here today. It took 17 long years for the coalition to return to the tactics it used in 1981, move a censure motion on an opposition member, and then gag the debate because it cannot hack it. We are dealing with a pathetic, miserable government. Senator Vanstone, you have been involved in these sorts of exercises because you were undermined by David Kemp, sacked by the Prime Minister, and bullied by the state governments over gun control. You are prone to invention under attack and you have never found a bad microphone yet.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Alston's ) be now put.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion to delete clause (c) of the motion.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —For clarification, could the entire new motion be read to the chamber.
—It is the motion on page 2 of the Notice Paper , deleting clause (c).

interjection.para: Motion (by Senator Harradine)—as amended, by leave—agreed to:

talk.start.para: —The question is that the motion moved by Senator Vanstone, as amended, be agreed to. All those in favour say aye; against say no. A division is required. Ring the bells for one minute.
—Ring the bells for four minutes.

interjection.para: That the motion (Senator Vanstone's ), as amended, be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

debate.para: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) proposed:
That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] , allowing it to be considered during this period of sittings.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, we have indicated, as you would be aware, that the opposition has taken the principal position that we do not want to be party to any procedural motion that would, if it were successfully carried in this chamber, have the effect of further delaying the Wik debate. This is a useful opportunity for the opposition to be able to state very clearly that we have heard the rhetoric from the government in relation to suggestions that the opposition is about delaying debate in the Senate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] . Exempting that bill from the provisions of standing order 111 puts the lie to that particular rhetoric. I do want to say on behalf of the opposition that we are willing to have this debate at any time of the government's choosing—that is, whenever the government believes it is appropriate to list the debate.

speech.para: It is very difficult, having seen the government's behaviour over the last couple of days, to really believe that the native title legislation is the highest priority on the government's legislative agenda. It is almost unheard of for a government that talks consistently about the pressure of its legislative program to bring on as an item of government business a censure motion on an opposition senator, but that has been the government's priority in this chamber for the last couple of days. We believe that of itself will make it very difficult for the government to argue a substantive case in relation to priority to be given to the native title legislation. When a government regards a censure motion against an opposition senator as higher than any of its legislative priorities, surely this is an issue that would warrant concern not only from all senators in this chamber, but also there must be a significant amount of public concern about that approach to the planning of the government's legislation program.

The key point that needs to be made here is that the exemption from the provisions of standing order 111 is something that appears to be a proposal that is only attractive to the coalition when it is in government. A history of this particular standing order is worth relating to the Senate in case any senators in this chamber have forgotten how it came about. It was originally a proposal that was sponsored by Senator Chamarette, who was a representative of the Western Australian Greens, but it was enthusiastically picked up by the coalition, then in opposition. When the Labor Party was in government, we pointed out the weaknesses of the cut-off motion. We pointed out the weaknesses of any standing order that constrained a government's capacity to effectively work through its legislation program. But that was never the view of the Liberals, that was never the view of the coalition, when they were in opposition.

Of course, we have seen the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ian Campbell) forced on very many occasion to come in here and move exemptions to this standing order. One wonders whether the government has started to think that the pious speeches it made about the cut-off resolution at the time when it so enthusiastically supported the cut-off standing order were perhaps ill thought through. We had at the time an opposition that did not approach its business in this chamber from the perspective of an alternative government. Labor, since it was defeated in the election in 1996, has never had that approach to dealing with the new government's legislation program. We have never had that approach. We approach these issues from the perspective of an alternative government. We approach this from the perspective of a political party that we think is likely to find itself on the other side of the chamber, probably in a few short months.

The rationale of the cut-off motion is that it ensures that all senators, and not only senators but others who have an interest in government legislation, have sufficient time to analyse legislation and formulate a view upon it. That has always been the rationale of the cut-off motion. The cut-off device ensures that there is sufficient time for this to occur between the introduction of a bill into the parliament and debate on that bill on the floor of the chamber. I think the government, from its perspective, first realised some of the weaknesses in this standing order when, as a newly elected government, it found a problem with the standing order's application to legislation brought in in the first period of sittings after the election.

But the point needs to be made to the Senate in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill that we do have legislation before the chair that is essentially the same as that which was debated in the Senate last November and December. I think that all senators would have to acknowledge the fact that that was a most extensive debate and one of the most complex committee stage considerations we had seen in this chamber. It is also worth noting that the minister responsible for han dling that legislation on behalf of the government, Senator Minchin, and the opposition shadow minister responsible for the legislation in the Senate, Senator Bolkus, both acknowledged that in summing up and concluding this debate. It also needs to be said that a range of other minor party and independent senators, many of whom played a very active role in that committee stage consideration, also acknowledged the fact that it had been a most intensive and complex committee stage consideration.

The issue before the Senate is one of whether, with the level of scrutiny of the legislation that took place in that exhaustive committee stage debate towards the end of last year, it is appropriate for the Senate to apply standing order 111—which I think we all colloquially refer to as the `cut-off motion'—in this circumstance. Is it appropriate for the Senate to apply this particular standing order to the native title legislation in the circumstances that I have outlined?

I will be interested to hear the case that is presented by those who do not support an exemption because, as far as the opposition is concerned, it is difficult to justify a denial of the exemption from the cut-off for this bill on the basis that we might need more time to understand the issues. At the time—and I would refer people back to—

talk.start.para: —It is not us who need any more time.
—Sorry, I did not hear what you said, Senator.
—He said, `It is not us who need the time.'
—Who is it, Senator? That is something that you might care to make a contribution on.
—He is pretty quick with his contributions. I have noticed that.

—I will take that dopey interjection from Senator Newman who said that he is pretty quick in his contributions. I would never accuse Senator Harradine of being quick in all his contributions. I think he acknowledges that by the nod of his head. Senator Newman, the contribution that I am making at this time is one I am surprised that you are not supportive of. This is a major issue for the government. You might be so out of touch with what your own government is proposing in relation to debate on the Wik legislation that you cannot understand that the government is proposing an exemption. This is an issue that has received a great deal—
—You take a lot longer to say it than needs to be taken.

—The difference between you and me, Senator Newman, is that I am capable of making a speech in the parliament and I am capable of participating in a committee stage debate; you are not. Who will ever forget you on the social security legislation? There you are propped up, with Senator Hill trying to hold you together on one side and Senator Alston on the other. It was very embarrassing. Senator Harradine and I were both very embarrassed by your performance. Frankly, Senator Newman, I think the less you say about this the better. Your best contribution to this debate probably would be to keep quiet because you do not even seem to understand that I am indicating on behalf of the opposition that the opposition is proposing to support the exemption in this particular case, which is something that the government is arguing—not that we have heard the case mounted by Senator Campbell.

speech.para: When I was manager of government business—and the place ran a lot better than it does now—I would always try to make a case for the exemption of a bill from the cut-off motion. I think Senator Harradine, Senator Woodley and Senator Margetts were here at that time. I acknowledge that Senator Brown did not have the pleasure of being here when I was managing government business. I would come in here and argue the case if an exemption to that standing order was proposed, particularly on a matter as important as this legislation is, not only to the parliament but also to the Australian community. I think even my worst enemy in politics would have to acknowledge that that is the case.
The point I am trying to make, Senator Newman, which, obviously, you are not capable of understanding because of your limitations, is that we believe that there has been—

talk.start.para: —You should make those points through the chair, Senator.

—What I was saying, Mr Acting Deputy President, was that apparently Senator Newman, because of her limitations, is not able to understand this argument. The opposition is not going to be in the business of opposing procedural motions before the chair in the Senate that might have the effect of delaying debate on the native title legislation. That is the point that I am making, and I am indicating that we believe there has been sufficient time to deal with this in terms of familiarisation with the issues. We are saying that the opposition is ready, willing and able to engage in that debate at any time that the government believes it ought to bring the debate on. We are not going to accept being accused of not being willing to debate this legislation in this current session of parliament. The government has indicated that it believes it is important that this matter be dealt with as soon as possible. We believe the behaviour of the government in the Senate over the past couple of days indicates that its priorities are elsewhere and, when you have got—as I have indicated before—a government willing to give so much time to a banal and pointless censure motion of an opposition senator, I think it does strain credulity to accept that the government is serious about this particular proposal.

speech.para: As far as the opposition is concerned, we point out that the government is proposing an exemption to a standing order of the Senate that historically the Labor Party has always viewed as having weaknesses. But we have accepted that this standing order is here to stay and that governments do need to ensure that their legislation program is planned in a way that allows adequate time for senators and the community to examine legislation. I also believe, and I want to make this point very clearly, that when legislation comes before the Senate the principle of introduction in one session for debate in the next is important. It is important that the Senate and governments are able to comply with those principles.

So some of the spirit of this standing order was certainly accepted by Labor when in government. We have always pointed out that you do have urgent legislation—budget related legislation and other legislation—that requires consideration by parliament in the same session as it is introduced. That has always been a weakness in this standing order. But you have to acknowledge that sometimes you have powerful arguments in these sorts of matters. Our powerful arguments have, in the past, not been accepted. So this standing order is here to stay. We accept that it is here to stay. It has to be applied in a sensible manner. What we say in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] is simple: we have had a lot of debate over the issue. We have had sufficient time. We all know the issues that are before us. The opposition are ready, willing and able to debate the issues. So we say, `Let's get on with it.' We will support the exemption.

talk.start.para: —Senator Faulkner has indicated that we do not need more time to consider or debate the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] . I think he has missed the point that the people who are most affected by this legislation are the ones who have never had it taken to them at any grassroots level. The haste with which the legislation was put through at the end of last year meant that there was no proper process of consultation with indigenous Australians. It was an extremely complex bill; it changed considerably over time; and there was never a time when those people most affected by the legislation had the ability to have a say and get around what was being proposed. This was brought very painfully to us when we saw an announcement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) about his option of putting indigenous leaders in a room with industry, shutting the door and saying, `You don't get out until you come to an agreement.'

speech.para: If that is what the Labor Party consider is a correct and proper consultative process then it is probably no wonder that they are today putting their hands up to exempt this bill from a cut-off. It is a bill which is not yet before the Senate. It is not a particularly good principle for us to be debating these cut-off exemptions when a bill is not as yet before the Senate. Senator Harradine has circulated an amendment to government business notice of motion No. 1 in which he is asking for the debate to be adjourned until after the bill is introduced into the Senate. I am inclined to support that, although there is no standing order that I know of which prevents the government from doing what they are doing, that is, pre-empting the end of the debate in the House of Representatives and the introduction of the bill into the Senate. More and more, Senate committees are being asked to deal with bills or the provisions of bills which are not before the Senate. In this particular case, I do not think it is proper process and I would not be prepared to accept this.

The process by which countries such as Canada have moved towards some sort of lasting solution on issues of sovereignty and land justice has not been attempted overnight. It has taken a number of years. Quite frankly, any real process would require, if there was any political will, a proper consultative process over time, not this kind of shove legislation through and threaten or even put people in a room, close the door and insist that they come up with a solution no matter how lacking that could possibly be in grassroots participation.

I believe that the Labor Party had a consistent view in relation to the cut-off motion. But from the Greens (WA) perspective, that consistent view was that it was the government's legislative program—as if they owned the outcome of the legislation; as if it was not affecting other people. It seemed to be a `thumbing their nose' at any real democracy and also seemed to go along with the idea of mandate and three-year elected dictatorships. So it is nice to hear Senator Faulkner acknowledging that there are benefits to the community and, obviously, the Senate in the principle that the Senate and the community have the chance to look at legislation and the way it has been drafted and to comment on it before we are required to vote on it. But it is disappointing to see that he has forgotten that there never was a full community consultation in relation to this bill. It did not happen last year and will not, potentially, happen this year if the opposition is prepared to let this through.

It is a great disappointment. It certainly is very telling that Senator Faulkner does not understand that we—that is, the Senate and the parliament of Australia—are not the only people who need to understand this bill. I will support Senator Harradine's amendment and indicate that if it is not passed I will vote against the exemption from the cut-off motion.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that the Australian Democrats will not support the cut-off motion. We will support Senator Harradine's amendment to it, which is a very sensible amendment and really would put everything in its proper order. One of the problems with what we are doing today is that due process has again been thrown out the window. I support everything that Senator Margetts has just said to us and would like to add some other very good reasons why this legislation is not in any sense urgent.

speech.para: The motion before us today is about exempting the 10-point plan of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) from the due process of the Senate. Standing order 111 was introduced and supported by the coalition parties to prevent the previous practice sometimes used in this place of legislation by ambush. That is a situation which means non-government senators would have quite complex legislation presented for their consideration with little or no time for proper deliberation. This motion was introduced to prevent that from happening. It has become known in this place as the cut-off motion.

In its wisdom the Senate also recognised that there are some instances where legislation could be justifiably—I emphasise `justifiably'—presented as urgent and that that legislation could be exempted from standing order No. 111. However, the 10-point plan is not urgent. It is at its very core a political stunt aimed at completing the final act of dispossession against indigenous Australians. It is immoral for any Australian government to attempt to prop up the failing popularity of a premier in my state by using indigenous people as a political football. This is one of the reasons why the Democrats will not support the cut-off motion.

We know that Mr Borbidge was here in Canberra this week for the specific purpose of lobbying the Prime Minister on this very issue. We know that he has no other issue in Queensland on which to fight an election. On almost every other issue he has shown himself to be absolutely bereft of policy or of any worthwhile action. Yet this government is prepared to go along and try to prop up the Queensland premier in his attempt to have an election based on the whole of the Wik issue, which, I might say, could not fail to be a race election.

The premier has already said that he is going to have an election in Queensland based on this issue. I point out to the Senate that just a couple of weeks ago he was in the press saying that people living in housing commission homes are losing their homes as a result of native title claims. It is a ridiculous assertion for which he had no legal advice whatsoever. In fact, he got advice from his media officer to run with this assertion because it looked like it might have been a good idea at the time. There was no legal support for the claim; nevertheless, he went ahead with it. At least one member of the Labor Party in Queensland phoned me when I pointed this out in the media and said, `Go for it. You're absolutely right.'

It is interesting also that in the week I had this debate with Premier Borbidge about the Wik issue I was phoned by a very embarrassed mill owner from the Gold Coast who had invited me and the premier to be present at the opening of a sugar mill. He was phoning me to say that I was no longer invited. You can imagine where the pressure came from for me to be uninvited to that opening.

talk.start.para: —No sweetener for you.

—No sweetener for me on that occasion. We have a premier who is desperate to win a state election and has no other issue to base it on other than this. I do not believe that the Senate ought to support that kind of politics in my home state—although we are quite used to it there.

speech.para: With this cut-off motion the government is pursuing, at its core, the abrogation of due process. It is an abrogation of due process to exempt legislation under the standing orders of the Senate when that legislation is not urgent. It is an abrogation of due process when the separation of powers under the constitution is not respected and conservative governments seek to legislate away the common law property rights of some Australians because of the colour of their skin. It is an abrogation of due process to use racism as the basis of an election in this country and to spend $60 million of taxpayers' money to pursue what is a gamble, which in the end will see constitutional backup for what the government is doing if it goes to a double dissolution and has a joint sitting of parliament following that.

It is an abrogation of due process to use this debate in this chamber to continue the oppression of the most disadvantaged groups of people in the Australian community. I remind the Senate that in eight weeks time there will be a decision handed down by the High Court which will have a bearing on the legitimacy or otherwise of the legislation which we are debating—that is, the Hindmarsh Island Bridge case. We ought to know the result of that case whichever way it goes so that we will be able to take that decision of the High Court into account in the debate.

I do not agree with the Prime Minister's premise—I hope the Labor Party do not agree with it; perhaps they can tell us—that people are sick of the Wik debate. I think the Prime Minister is sick of the Wik debate and I think some people in his party are sick of the Wik debate because it is turning against them. Out there in the public arena people are waking up to what this government is seeking to do. Certainly out there in the public arena the debate is turning against the government. The people are not sick of the Wik debate, but they certainly are taking sides in the debate and, increasingly, they are not on the side of the government.

Are we to return to the 210 years of terra nullius, to the legal invisibility of our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people? During the first round of debates on the 10-point plan, I noted the absence of indigenous people in this chamber. I again draw the attention of the Senate to that fact. Because of that absence, it is morally incumbent on each and every senator in this place to listen to what indigenous Australians are telling us.

I know the Aboriginal people have told the Labor Party that they should delay this bill. Why doesn't the Labor Party take that advice? The people have told us they need time to try to convince the Prime Minister that there is another way to go. In today's press Gatjil Djerrkura again repeated this offer and underlined that that was the agreement which he reached with the Prime Minister when the Prime Minister was in Arnhem Land just a couple of weeks ago. Surely we can hear this appeal.

As Senator Harradine indicated before, it is not whether you or I or any senator in this place has had time to debate the issue. What really is important in this place—I underline what Senator Margetts said—is that the Aboriginal people have time to negotiate with us, the Prime Minister and all of those involved a proper outcome for this debate and this legislation.

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) has put our position, and Senator Woodley, in his usual courteous fashion, has put arguments to the contrary. He says, for example, that time ought to be made available for people to convince the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that he ought to change his position. I would have been more impressed with that argument had the Australian Democrats not supported the gag motion earlier this morning, cutting off the opportunity we on this side had to convince the chamber that a particular argument ought prevail. For the Democrats to now talk about time being made available to convince people is rather hollow.

speech.para: Senate Woodley also pointed out in his argument that due process should be preserved. This is from a man whom I have a great respect for but who, this very morning, voted to gag debate before people had an opportunity to put a case and then voted against the person about whom the motion was put. I say with due respect to Senator Woodley that his arguments about due process and time being made available are not in keeping with the way that he and his party acted this morning.

The Greens, Senator Brown and Senator Margetts, and Senator Harradine, as an Independent, at least voted for due process and, having been defeated with the assistance of the Democrats, then voted a particular way. I can understand that. But I cannot understand the argument Senator Woodley, who comes from a party which supported gagging debate to censure a man who is now visited with that opprobrium for the rest of his life, put when he voted to deny the person concerned the opportunity of having a proper defence put. That the Democrats are debating the matter that has come on after that in a way contrary to how they conducted themselves earlier this morning is a little hard to take.

Senator Woodley says this matter is one that does not need to come on early. He spoke about the business of the indigenous people of Australia. To my way of thinking, the business of the indigenous people of Australia should be foremost in our minds and we should be ready to bring that on for debate now.

Senator Woodley, in opposing this motion, introduced material and debated it on a basis that would indicate that he is well abreast of the arguments that are to be put for and against this bill. It has been said, and I think said with some truth, that the government is about this bill being a trigger for a double dissolution, and no doubt it will be said that the Labor Party is in the same game, as it were. That is not true. The Labor Party wants a regime in Australia that serves the people of Australia well, whether they be pastoralists, indigenous people, miners or what have you.

The Australian Labor Party is about putting forward a scheme which gets Australians working together and which gets Australia properly developed, developed in a way that gives the proper respect to those indigenous people that have worked towards this over the years—people like Geoff Clark from Framlingham, Monica Morgan from the north of Victoria and her mother, Elizabeth Hoffman; those sorts of people who are desperate to see a proper solution reached in this area; people who have laboured over the years towards a situation where a proper result is obtained.

It is clear, in the way we put things, that the government's legislation is flawed. We on this side of the chamber showed just how badly it was flawed the last time it was before this chamber. The government wants to bring that legislation on again and go through those matters. Let us hope they can be convinced. Let us hope they do bring that legislation back here on the basis that they are willing to listen to debate.

But that proposition—the proposition that they should reconsider—looks as if it is not going to be accepted. It seems that their minds are made up, just like the minds of the coalition and the minds of the Democrats were made up about Senator Bolkus this morning when that matter was brought up. That is a pity. It is a pity that the government, in bringing back this legislation, is not susceptible to good argument. There was good argument put last time by this side of the chamber, and indeed by the Democrats and Senator Harradine. I thought that was quite outstanding—I think that has been accepted—in the debate last time on this bill. There were quite outstanding arguments, too, by Senator Margetts and Senator Brown.

talk.start.para: —What about me?

—Senator Boswell, you did it with style and a flourish. The only thing wrong with your arguments was that they were in error. Senator Boswell, I think that your heart is a great heart; but it is misdirected in this particular debate. I ask whether Senator Boswell has a broad enough mind in the political sense—I do not mean in the intellectual sense—to accept the arguments that are put against the position that he takes up.

speech.para: You are loyal. I continue with the very relevant matter that Senator Boswell has raised. Senator Boswell, you want to support the pastoralists. You want to support those people in Queensland who feel threatened by native title claims. That is understandable. But, Senator Boswell, you have to remember that we are here to represent all Australians. The argument should not be, `I have a particular problem up there. I have a particular constituency to service.' We have all got that. This is such a great issue that we should debate this matter that you have talked about with open minds.

talk.start.para: —We are going to bring on social security if you are going to filibuster.
—Order! Senator Campbell, if you want to have a discussion, I suggest you have it outside the chamber or some other place where you are not interrupting—
—Order! Senator Campbell, there is a senator on his feet who is speaking. It is a breach of the standing orders to interrupt that. If you wish to have a discussion, then leave the chamber.

—I understand Senator Campbell's position. He has no doubt other business to bring on—the business not only of the indigenous people of Australia but also of the pastoralists of Queensland and of the miners of Western Australia. Senator McKiernan, who sits next to me, is a great Western Australian.
—That is true; yes, he is.

—Yes. He is always urging the interests of Western Australians upon me, including the miners. It is important that we bring on the debate in accordance with what the government wants. But what I want to make clear is that, in bringing on the debate, we do not take positions where we simply come here with fixed minds. I think I can get from the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate, Senator Carr, a clear undertaking that we will listen to the arguments. But we are dedicated to making sure that all the people of Australia get what is right.
—But you are not doing that. Voting for the cut-off is not doing that.
—And that is the problem, Senator Cooney.

—I take up the remarks of Senator Harradine and Senator Woodley. They say that voting for the cut-off is not doing that. But, as I understand the way the government puts it and the way we have accepted it on this side, this matter is of importance, given the fact that the indigenous people have been held out of their land for such a length of time and given the fact that the pastoralists and the miners want a quick resolution of this matter. We can see what the government is about.

speech.para: In answer to Senator Harradine and Senator Woodley, I will quote from a statement by Senator Carr, the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate, who made this statement on 29 May 1996:
I would perhaps start by reminding senators of the terms of the order of continuing effect, which is commonly referred to as the Hill cut-off motion. In effect that motion says:
The reasons referred to in paragraph (1) are as follows:—
He goes on—
- in terms of why there should be a cut-off motion in place—
Then the motion goes on:

(a) there should be an orderly debate of bills in accordance with some of the general chronological priority based on the principle that bills introduced in one sitting, should preferably be debated in the next sittings;
(b) that such a priority reflects and ensures effective use of the time available:
(i) to Senators, to research the implications of the bills, consult the community, prepare speech notes and draft any necessary amendments, and
(ii) to the media and to the public to become aware of the possible effects of proposed laws; and

(c) where the government wishes the Senate to depart from that general chronological priority, the government should justify each such departure in debate which concludes with a resolution of agreement by the Senate.

Going through that—the issue of the orderly debate of bills in accordance with some general chronological priority based on the principle that bills introduced in one sitting should preferably be debated in the next sitting—this is a bill that has been debated once already, for just over 56 hours.

Let me make it clear that the arguments are important and it is essential, when this bill comes on again, that the bill is debated fully with the issues aired. The point made in reference to the general principles given to me by Senator Carr—and I thank him for that—is that the ability to have an orderly debate is there because of the arguments that have already been raised.
As I said, part (b) says:
that such a priority reflects and ensures effective use of the time available:
(i) to Senators, to research the implications of the bills—
There has certainly been time to research the implications of the bill, and there has been time for the media and the public to become aware of the possible effects of the proposed law.

Senator Woodley said, `Yes, but perhaps we can get to the point where the Prime Minister can be lobbied and all these other things should be done.' I do not think that is the right approach to take in terms of whether or not you give priority to this bill. The issue is not whether or not a deal can be done but, firstly, whether or not senators can research the implications of the bill; secondly, whether or not the public has become aware of the possible effects of the proposed bill; and, thirdly, whether the government should justify each such departure. In deciding those questions, I think we have to decide them in terms of debates in this chamber and not so much in terms of whether or not we hope that history will somehow change outside.

The points raised by Senator Woodley certainly have merit, but they have to be regarded in the context of what the parameters ought to be in deciding this particular debate, which is a debate about whether or not stand ing order 111 should be looked at so as to exempt this particular bill. The approach of the opposition on this matter is to allow that to happen, and what I am doing now is explaining why. The philosophical reason behind this side of the chamber doing it is that we do think that the affairs of the indigenous people are important. They have been shut out from their rights for 210 years. It is proper that their rights be vindicated as soon as possible. The fact that they have had to wait all this time is no reason for them to wait longer.

In that context, the fact that the miners and the pastoralists want a clarification of the situation are also reasons. I think Senator Woodley is right. I do not think the people of Australia are sick of this. They want the matter resolved, but they want it resolved fairly and justly for all parties. The sooner that is clarified the better. The matter will come in here, and I hope a full debate takes place because this matter deserves a full debate—

talk.start.para: —Without being gagged.
—That is true. Perhaps I should ask Senator Woodley that.
—You still have two minutes to take up your full 20 minutes.
—I think Senator Campbell makes a good point—that I have two minutes to take up my 20 minutes. I think the point he is making is that this is a matter that should be debated fully.
—At great length, obviously!

—At great length. I would like some assurance from the Democrats—and I do not want the answer now, Senator Woodley, but perhaps you could talk about this in the party room—that they will not gag this debate in the way that they gagged the debate on the very rare occasion of a censure motion being brought against a non-minister in this chamber. In those circumstances they cut off debate without this side having a chance to put a defence in favour of that man. I would like an assurance that the Democrats will undertake not to put a gag on this very important debate of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] . I have not taken up my full 20 minutes, Senator Campbell.

—I oppose this motion because I agree with Senator Margetts and other speakers who have made the point that this is a matter of critical public importance and the public needs to be taken into account. Senator Christabel Chamarette was not in this place for a great length of time, but she had a remarkable impact as far as making it more democratic.
—Who?

—Senator Patterson, you need to read history; I am not surprised that you do not know. One remarkable innovation that Senator Chamarette was able to have accorded to the Senate was the business of not allowing bills to be brought in here and debated immediately.

speech.para: The problem with that process as it used to be was that the public was left out. Opposition senators did not have time to go to their constituencies, nor did the constituencies have time to feed back their feelings, about legislation, which was often amended, coming from the House of Representatives.

So it was an important principle, the coalition supported it at the time, and we ought not put it aside lightly. In particular, we ought not put it aside lightly in dealing with legislation which is as important as this is to the first Australians—the indigenous people of this nation.

Let me reiterate that this piece of legislation on native title is going to impact on Australian life for the next century, and possibly well beyond it. It is very important that the nation have time to feed into it. What I am concerned about is that there will not be the same result this time around as there was last time; that there are shifting sands, and that the government is aware of that and feels it is moving to some sort of conclusion which will be to its benefit and to the detriment of the indigenous people of this country.

There are critical matters here. The threshold test for native title claimants: will it be altered by the stand that the Senate takes next time around? There is the provision for the legislation to be under the sway of the Racial Discrimination Act; also, the right to negotiate on mining on pastoral leases. We know already, with the major components in here, the Labor Party and the coalition, not having stood firm on the right to negotiate on the upgrade of pastoral leases on other things than mining—on a whole range of things—that there has been an enormous diminution in the expectation that the indigenous people would have a right to negotiate on a whole range of changes to their land as development engulfs the north of this country in the coming century.

If there are shifting sands in connection with any component of this Senate—be it the Greens, the Democrats, Senator Harradine, Senator Colston, the Labor Party, and in particular the government—then the public has a right to know about that before the debate gets under way. In particular, the indigenous people of this country have a right to know about that before the debate gets under way, so that they can feed their response to those changes back to us, the elected representatives, who at the end of the day have to cast a vote on this critical matter. If the government has its way, we will be forced to do that on the run.

I do not support doing that on the run. This is far too important, and it is a matter of high democratic principle. The people most involved in this matter—a matter which will affect not just their lives but the lives of their children and their children's children—must know what the amendments mean to this legislation and have time to feed back to their elected representatives their support, their opposition or their wish for change.

I have a feeling that serially, every time we deal with this legislation, the rights of the indigenous people are being eroded; their import into what happens to their lives and their land is being eroded. I am mightily alarmed about that, and I am not the only one. The feedback that I get—as Senator Margetts has already indicated that she is getting—is that Australians are very concerned about this, and they want to have their say.

I oppose this move by the government to relegate this legislation to being just another piece of legislation that can be rushed through. That is not the proper way to be handling it. There should be due time. We and the government and the opposition should be observing due process. Above all, we should be insisting that the wider Australian public have time to feed into whatever changes any component of this Senate makes.

Let me put this to the Labor Party in particular: if you are to change position, if you believe that the government is changing position, if you think there will be a different outcome this time around, you have an obligation to the indigenous people and to the wider populace of this country to ensure that they are taken into confidence so that they have time to let you know what they think of any changed position.

The same applies, of course, as I said, to all other components of this House, including Senator Harradine—and the government. I know there are negotiations about this going on all over the place. But the public out there does not.

talk.start.para: —What negotiations?

—The papers have stated that you have been negotiating with the government, Senator Faulkner, in recent times; you have been talking with the government about this legislation. I do not think the public are fully acquainted with that, and they ought to be. That is my point. So, as a representative of the Australian Greens, I for one will be standing firmly against change to the forms of this place which insist that we take time. This legislation must not be brought in here one day and debated the next.

—I might need to continue what I am about to say when we come back to this issue, because I have only 20 seconds now. I was not going to speak on this question, but I feel it is necessary to answer some of the inaccurate arguments put forward by particularly Senator Cooney from the Labor Party. For that reason, I need to speak as to why it is not appropriate that we exempt this bill from the normal process.

speech.para: Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under standing orders, we will now proceed to the matters of public interest debate.

—I rise today as a senator from Victoria to discuss the very important issue of waterfront reform. The Victorian business environment is robust and the state government is very supportive of business enterprise. I was not surprised that the NFF chose to situate their new business at Melbourne ports.

speech.para: Victorian businesses, farmers, horticulturalists and others in the business area are among the most competitive in the world. They are efficient, well organised and have taken up the challenge to expand their businesses through overseas exports with enthusiasm. Their enthusiasm for export and keen eye for new business opportunities prompted me in my capacity as the parliamentary representative to the Australian mission to the United Nations to take a particular interest in multilateral procurement.

The interest which greeted all of my discussions on this issue with Victorian business representatives left no doubt in my mind that Victorian enterprises could and should gain a greater slice of the multi-million dollar international multilateral procurement business. I had many discussions with the heads of international procurement agencies. I was told by both the World Bank, which I visited on two occasions in Washington, and the United Nations procurement officers that they would like to do more business with Australians.

I was told innumerable times how good we were at supplying consultants, what a tremen dous reputation Australia has in supplying consultants to the United Nations and the World Bank and yet how we fell down on supplying goods.

In order to win procurement contracts, Australian businesses must be involved in the process and be active participants. Also, they have to have the preliminary qualification of guaranteeing a reliable supply of the relevant goods.

The Committee for Melbourne—a committee which has been established to promote Melbourne, Victoria and businesses—has in fact worked assiduously in the multilateral procurement area and has secured the United Nations procurement conference, which is a conference of officers from the United Nations who purchase goods and services who have a meeting once a year. The Committee for Melbourne has secured that conference for Melbourne next year. That was one of reasons they asked me to get involved and meet as many of the procurement officers as possible.

The Committee for Melbourne is also working towards establishing a World Bank partnership centre in Melbourne—and hopefully a centre which also includes United Nations activities—to provide a focus for not only Victorian businesses, but also Australian businesses to get in at the ground level and learn about the sorts of things that the United Nations is purchasing and the sorts of things that the World Bank is doing. One of messages that I received when I was at the World Bank and the United Nations was that you need to be involved in the preliminary stage so that, when the actual tenders are let, you have more knowledge of the process. Sometimes we are coming into it too late in the process. I commend the Committee for Melbourne for the work that it is doing to assist Victorian and Australian businesses to get involved.

Australian businesses are very responsive. When I was visiting the Antarctic I got to know the helicopter company down there that was responsible for all the flights and the servicing of the helicopters in the Antarctic. They are a Western Australian company. I rang them and said, `The United Nations wants to send helicopters. Would you be interested in getting involved with them?' They said, `Look, if we can deliver a helicopter service in the Antarctic, we can deliver it anywhere in the world. That is the toughest environment.'

There are Australian companies that are keen to get in there and do it. They are keen to be involved in this multilateral procurement, but it is no good if cannot get the goods from the production point to overseas points, especially in multilateral procurement, and get it there on a timely basis. It is just counter-productive.

I am naturally concerned that, even as all levels of government strive to assist businesses with their exports, even as the Committee for Melbourne is working towards establishing a World Bank partnership centre and a UN procurement centre in Melbourne, and even as the Minister for Trade is busily promoting Australian exports overseas, Australian businesses cannot make this basic guarantee of reliable delivery.

I have given the example of my father's business before. He manufactures artists' paints and poster paints. He had two orders from America some years ago two years in a row. One lot was left sitting on the wharf in the heat. The tubes exploded because the containers became too hot. They were sitting there during a strike and he did not get the delivery to the American market in time for the school year. He was trying to even out his production over a year. He had a peak period here for the beginning of the school year in Australia and a peak period in July/August for the American market. He tried to maintain jobs here in Australia and he had to put people on and off to meet the peaks and troughs in his business.

In the second year there was another strike and he did not get the paints to America on time. What happened was that he set up a subsidiary company in Canada and 12 jobs went to Canada. This was mainly because our wharves were so inefficient and he was delayed. It was only a very small business with 35 employees, but 12 jobs went down the drain and became Canadian jobs. So, that is the sort of thing that happens when our wharves are not reliable. Businesses make other decisions. They cannot afford to invest money, make losses or get a reputation for being an unreliable supplier.

An international survey of reliability was reported by the Herald Sun on 31 January this year. Melbourne came a miserable seventeenth on the scale of how well we performed as a supplier. On value for money we did one point better; we went to sixteenth position. Our waterfront strike action is 10 times the national average. It is the only area in which the Australian waterfront leads the world. We lead on the worst score.

The National Institute of Labour Studies at Flinders prepared a report late last year which shows that the level of industrial disputation on the waterfront is second only to the coal mining industry. Every day around Australia there is a stoppage. You think about that. That is some paints that are not going to be delivered on time or some food that might spoil. That is another group of businesses who are seen as unreliable suppliers in overseas markets. Every day there is a stoppage, a go-slow or some other form of interruption to service, resulting in ships missing sailings.

Ships regularly calling into Australia build several extra days into their schedules to allow for delays, damaging Australia's reputation as a trading partner. It is damaging the reputations as reliable suppliers of each of those businesses, small and large.

It is clear that Victorian businesses are not hampered by the tyranny of distance. They are hampered by the tyranny of disruption and delay on the waterfront, particularly on the Victorian waterfront. As proof of this point, another nation, even further from the major European and North American centres of commerce, New Zealand, has managed to overcome its tyranny of distance with its extremely efficient waterfront operations. I will quote Mr Ron Longley, who runs a shipping line exclusively between Australia and New Zealand and who would be more qualified, I suppose, than anyone else to make a comparison on waterfront costs in both nations. When he was asked how much more expensive Australia was, he replied:

Over three hundred per cent more than New Zealand, and that is on a like per like basis for a ship calling into a New Zealand port or into an Australian port and getting exactly the same services at both ports.

With a like to like comparison, we are 300 per cent more expensive than New Zealand. Australian waterfront productivity levels are woefully below those of our competitors. Auckland manages 25 crane movements per hour compared with Australia's average of 18.3. Auckland wharves are 37 per cent more productive than Australian wharves. Thai ports average 30 movements per hour, which is 64 per cent more productive than Australian ports. All of this is after a $400 million investment in the last three years by the major Australian stevedores to bring their terminal equipment up to date. With figures showing virtually no movement in productivity over the last year, this is a demoralising example of the problems that exist on our waterfront.

As I travel throughout Victoria, I am often asked how it was possible that the Labor government managed to rack up so much debt. I do not blame people for finding it hard to believe the size of the Beazley black hole, but it is due to grossly incompetent economic management. It is hard to credit this, even from the Labor Party, but it is true. There was enormous mismanagement.

One example I often use is the Labor government's $420 million waterfront industry reform authority process used, as former minister Graham Richardson put it, `to bribe the wharfies into retirement'. That is what the former minister said, `to bribe the wharfies into retirement'—$420 million. Labor's attempts at waterfront reform, the much maligned WIRA process, cost the nation $420 million. After the money had been paid in redundancies and other outlays, the monetary improvement in productivity and reliability fell away, and the restrictive work practices again brought the Australian waterfront back to a level far behind our international competitors.

When I explain that the previous government paid $420 million to `bribe wharfies into retirement' and that, as a result of this investment today, our five port average crane rate of 18 per cent per hour is currently 45 per cent below the modest Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics benchmark of 25 containers per hour, peoples' jaws drop. Then they understand very quickly how we got so disastrously into debt.

We have paid $420 million, and we are no better off. That $420 million to retire about 5,000 wharfies is a very generous rates for mates deal, even by the standards of the Australian Labor Party. The unproductive and unreliable nature of Australian waterfronts is compounded by featherbedding, restrictive work practices, overmanning and rorts.

When I was down in the Antarctic on the Aurora Australis with members of the Australian Seamens Union and other unions, I saw what those union fellows could do when they really needed to, when they really wanted to. When they realised that people's lives were at stake and that it cost $70,000 every day that ship was late, they worked in minus 10 degree temperatures. They worked in blizzards, they worked in the freezing cold, and they worked on Christmas Day. They were fine examples of what people can do when they put their minds to it. They were tremendous examples of union guys who, when they decided that they were going to be productive, could do it. They showed the sort of example that could be set. Around the wharves in Australia, if the temperature drops to nought degrees, the wharfies will stop work. These guys were working in minus 10 degrees—freezing; your hands froze on to the steel—and they were working in slippery conditions.

I said to people, `Isn't this an example of what can be done when people feel a commitment to the Antarctic project?' What we want to see from the waterfront workers—and there are many of them, I am sure, who have a commitment to Australia—is a demonstration of that commitment. We want to see them putting themselves where their mouths are, showing that commitment. We know it is possible.

The Maritime Union of Australia's claim to be interested in productivity is belied by its actions in rejecting an Arbitration Commission recommendation on 20 October 1997 that it improve productivity to a modest 22 containers per hour before laying claim to further benefits. The MUA will not agree to further reform unless Patrick Stevedores agrees to a guaranteed minimum wage of $75,000, plus improved superannuation benefits.

Practices such as two up, two down manning, eliminated in New Zealand half a dozen years ago, are still practised on the Australian waterfront. One outstanding example of inefficiency is the procedure for unloading cars on the waterfront. At Webb Dock, a car gang comprises 29 wharfies, including the supervisor. Of the 29 men, only 15 drive the cars off the ships, three men are supervisors, three men are on clerical duties—there must be so much paperwork involved in unloading cars that you need three men—one man to direct traffic with a flag, three men to provide taxi services to save walking back on board and four men to unlash cars. When the men are on ordinary time, productivity is three cars per man hour. When the men are on double time, and are allowed to knock off after all cars are unloaded, productivity soars to 7.5 cars per hour per man—an increase of 150 per cent.

I can go on and on. High costs, low productivity and unreliability on the waterfront are hampering the ability Australian businesses in general, and Victorian businesses in particular, from fulfilling their export potential.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Labor Party has a long and proud tradition of serving the interests of the ordinary working people of Australia. That tradition has been built up over more than 100 years by the efforts of so many committed and dedicated men and women. On 11 December 1997 the labour movement lost one of its finest servants with the passing away of Edgar Williams. Edgar Williams was a giant of a man in every sense of the phrase. His service to the union movement, the Australian Labor Party and, more importantly, the Australian Workers Union and ordinary Queenslanders, for more than 50 years was unrivalled.

speech.para: Edgar was born in Alexandria, New South Wales, on 11 April 1911 and left school at 13 to become a messenger boy at a music company in Sydney. But that did not last long. In 1925 Edgar went west, working on properties until he started shearing in western New South Wales in 1927. In 1929 Edgar went to Queensland and from then until 1943 he followed the shearing trails, mostly in the western districts of Longreach, Blackall, Winton and Isisford.

In July 1943 Edgar took up his first official role in the Australian Workers Union as an organiser in the western district, a position he held until becoming western district secretary in 1947, stationed at Longreach. In 1950 he transferred to Townsville as northern district secretary. This position gave Edgar a wider responsibility and more experience as it took in the sugar industry and the mining industry in Mt Isa. He was there for 10 years. In January 1960 he became Queensland branch secretary, a position he held until retirement in May 1982. Those 22 years and five months made Edgar the longest serving secretary of the Queensland branch, a record that will probably never be broken. For 17 of those 22 years Edgar was also the federal president of the Australian Workers Union. In those nearly 40 years as a full-time official Edgar had one thing in mind—better working conditions for his members.

So it is appropriate for me to look briefly at some of the record of Edgar Williams and his devotion to his beloved union—the Australian Workers Union—and also to the people whom he represented through that union. Edgar rose from very humble begin nings. By 1957, before affiliation of the AWU with the ACTU, Edgar was nominated and elected by the ACTU to the Mines—other than coal—Conference in Geneva. He went on in his career to do three months with the Leader Grant program in the United States. He served on delegations with the trade union movement in West Germany, Israel, Russia and China.
Edgar will be remembered also for the book which he published in 1967. The Australian Worker, a publication put out by the Australian Workers Union, of 31 August 1983, said:

In 1967 Edgar's book, "Yellow, Green and Red" was published. It views the industrial scene, particularly the Mt Isa strikes of the 1960's in which he was one of the leading figures. In his book Edgar airs his dislike of communists.
It was this open expression of his low opinion of communists that brought throughout his career unabashed attempts by some of his opponents to discredit him . . . all failed.
The article goes on to give a further insight into Edgar Williams. It says:
His reputation for integrity as well as for his skill as a top Union negotiator earned him the further respect of friend and adversary alike.
The article goes on:
He had, he says, no ambition, he only wanted to assist fellow workers.

This is the quality of the worker. The article goes on to say that on two occasions Edgar was offered safe seats in the state parliament but declined. It was also made apparent in the article that Edgar was offered an opportunity to become an industrial commissioner. But, again, he rejected that because on all occasions Edgar put as his priority the needs of representing the working people who were members of his union.

Edgar was a great man who treated all of those he met equally regardless of who they were or their position. One of the best examples of this was when he first met a young Bob Hawke. Prior to Bob Hawke's arrival at the ACTU, the major industrial cases had been conducted for the ACTU by Dick Eggleston, QC. When it was announced that Bob Hawke would be replacing him for the 1959 basic wage case, Edgar wrote the headline for the Australian Worker, the official paper of the AWU, `From Eggleston to Egghead.' But as Bob Hawke said after Edgar's death, `I came to develop a warm and effective relationship with Edgar Williams, truly a giant figure in the history of the Australian trade union movement.'

Even after his retirement as a full-time official in 1982, Edgar was never very far from his beloved union. Hardly a week went by without Edgar visiting the union office either to just drop in to say hello or to offer advice that may have been sought by his successors.

Edgar also made a massive contribution to the Australian Labor Party over 50 years. In 1983 he was given due recognition when he was awarded life membership of the ALP. As further recognition of his contribution to Australian industrial relations, Edgar was awarded an Order of Australia in 1989. In 1995 the ACTU congress awarded him a certificate of honour in recognition of a lifetime of service to trade unionism and the Australian labour movement.

My memories of Edgar go back to 1976 when I became an official of the SDA, the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association. At that stage our union rented premises at Dunstan House, which was owned by the AWU. We used to get to meet Edgar on a number of occasions. From my first meeting with Edgar, he always greeted me with, `Good morning, young fella' or `Good afternoon, young fella.' He was very polite in his approach to life. The only problem that I had with that greeting was that for the next 21 years, until Edgar's death, I got the same greeting, which probably said something about my youthful outlook on life and my youthful appearance.

Edgar was a very private man. He did not seek publicity. He was very much a person who kept to himself. I always remember Edgar at ALP state conferences in Queensland. You could always bet that whenever a ballot was on, Edgar would be one of the first in line for his ballot papers. That was until the last state conference that was held in June 1997.
