To show the tenacity of the man, on that occasion, Edgar had gone out to do some shopping during a luncheon break. There was a ballot due to close not long after lunch and Edgar had failed to show to vote. I met him in the corridor. He had blood over his shirt and he had broken his glasses. But so fixed was he with his obligation to cast his vote and his commitment so strong that Edgar signed for his ballot paper, filled out the ballot paper and deposited the ballot paper with the returning officer before seeking medical attention.

Edgar's iron will and commitment came from his days as a shed hand and shearer in the tough areas of Western Queensland and New South Wales. Edgar will always be remembered as one of the great leaders of the Australian Workers Union, touching the lives of generations of Australian workers. As long as there is an Australian Workers Union, the spirit of Edgar Williams will live on. We lament his passing.

talk.start.para: —The review of Commonwealth legislation is something I want to discuss today, and to argue that it has been made extremely difficult—that is, the debate about this question by the government's discussion paper which is at best vague and at worst deliberately misleading. I would argue that the reason the detail is missing from this document is to confuse the public and to give the government an out every time those hard questions are asked of it. I have gone through the document and I would like to take this opportunity to point out some of those glaring problems.

speech.para: I hope that the government will listen to these arguments and that they will take these views seriously because I know that my concerns reflect those of very many Australians. The paper vaguely refers to an appropriate role for the Commonwealth without defining that role. The nearest we get to seeing the government's opinion on this matter is when it refers over and over again to unacceptable delays for developments and the states and local government needing more of a role. It seems to me that the collapse of 20 pieces of environment legislation into four watered down acts is simply to hasten both the time lines and the numbers of developments which have an impact on the environment.

So what is the Commonwealth's appropriate role on the environment? The Democrats argue that it should be much more substantial, hence, our private member's bill, which would put the environment into the constitution. The government's paper could have presented varying opinions on this matter in order to promote an informed public policy debate, but obviously it did not want to do that. It clearly has an agenda to wind back the levels of protection and leave them up to the states. It is on this matter that I have very major concerns. We have all seen state premiers in undignified brawls over who gets what sporting event. We have seen them offer subsidies and all sorts of attractions to bring certain industries into their states. Often this is at the expense of residents' tax bills.

My concern with the states assuming so much power with environmental decisions is that we will end up with a kind of Dutch auction. I can hear the calls right now. We will have Queensland saying, `Come to Queensland. We'll offer you good subsidies which are quite reasonable'—for that we should read low—`and conditions on your environmental safeguards'. Then Victoria will be saying, `No, come to Victoria. We can do a Queensland and have even lower standards than you.' The voice from the west would have its own trump card and they would say, `Come here and we will give you your very own act.' I believe it encourages the states to get into lower and lower bidding wars on the environment. That is not in the best interests of the environment that sustains us.

Another concern I have is that the minister will have to make a decision within four weeks of the matter being referred. Four weeks is a very short time frame when you consider the number of years that some of Australia's biggest conservation campaigns have taken. During this time there have been massive public awareness campaigns and places protected.

The government may think this is not relevant when compared to a few fossil fuel industry jobs or the odd mine, but I would contend that there has been so much spin-off from tourism that the economics are clearly on our side, as it were. The government bases the changes on the fact that some of the environment legislation is 20 years old. There are many acts of parliament which are still in use that are much more than 20 years old. The logical consequence of that kind of argument is that we should change all acts. The argument does not work, as the government has singled out a particular area for massive reform. It is clear that the government's concerns are not solely about the environment.

I turn to more specifics. The government is taking 20 acts, turning them into three and only asking us for a comment on the first two. They will all be connected, so the government is asking for our comments blindfolded in some senses. Just one illustration of this is the fact that the act hinges on a trigger mechanism about places of national significance, yet the government says that this definition is not to be presented to us at this stage.

How are we expected to make up our minds whether or not this is a good idea? The government has not given the definition or the way that it will work. The government goes on to refer to a test of national significance. This is even more sloppy and misleading. The government says that it will be tightly defined, so it is another trigger and will not be defined until enactment of the third bit of legislation—not when the discussion paper is out, not when the first two bills are brought in and sent to committee and not even when they are in the Senate. It will not be defined when the third bill comes in but when it is all over and when it is enacted. Even taking this into account, we are supposed to trust the government. The government has not given us any reasons so far for this kind of staging.

This matter reminds me of the Larsen cartoon about a scientist who has heaps of calculations on a board and then more calculations at the bottom. In the middle there is a blank spot saying, `And then a miracle occurs.' Then another scientist says, `I think the government will have to be more specific here, Henderson.' What miracles is the government waiting for? Why is the government not giving us the information we need and why such a short time frame for comment?

This process has been going on since the coalition got into government. The government is rushing to get this legislation into parliament before the end of the April sittings. I predict that the government will make mistakes as a result of that. The government has already realised just how complicated it will be to change the heritage act and to roll into this, which is why the government had to drop it from the discussion paper at the last minute.

The government made mistakes over the Natural Heritage Trust. Hopefully, they will be learning their lessons from that. The government has made the reform of environment legislation debate as confusing and as misleading as they can. I think they showed me yesterday in question time that the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) will not answer reasonable questions on this matter.

I need to say, however, that I will be tracking and thoroughly examining this and calling the government to account all the way through. I would like to call on the minister to stop drafting the bill until the public submission phase is over. Indeed, during the minister's answer in the Senate yesterday, he made it sound like it was a consequential process. He said, `Then there will be drafting.' So stop the drafting. I know you are doing it because you have an agenda and it does not matter what the public say.

The Democrats are asking the minister to carefully consider and evaluate those comments from the discussion paper first. Then when we have the detail, put out a draft bill for public comment and tell us how the heritage component will work. We need to see the specifics so that we can consider whether this package is better or worse for the environment in the overall scheme of things. Give the community more than four weeks. I say again that there is absolutely no need to rush this bill.

talk.start.para: —The announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) this week that reforms will be introduced to provide equity of access to superannuation in the event of a marriage breakdown is further evidence of this government's commitment to the principles of equity and sharing. The current inequities in the treatment of superannuation when a marriage breaks down were identified over 10 years ago, yet absolutely nothing was done about it by the previous Labor government.

speech.para: The government recognises that superannuation has not always provided women in particular with the security they need and deserve in retirement. The issue is an important one when it is taken into account that in 1996, 52,000 Australian couples applied for a divorce. This government has acted and introduced measures already to address the needs of women, including the low income spouse superannuation rebate, to help women outside the paid work force. Another measure introduced by the government has been the added versatility provided by the retirement savings accounts. Now the government is actively working to introduce reforms to bring about greater fairness and certainty into the treatment of superannuation in the event of a marriage breakdown.

The situation at present is that often a women forgoes the economic benefits which are derived from working to enable her partner to go to work and save via a superannuation fund. The woman forgoes work and makes sacrifices for her husband and family and the husband is able to translate some of those sacrifices into a compulsory savings program or superannuation.

On any view, the woman has made an indirect, but nonetheless tangible, contribution to that form of family savings. The problem arises in that if the couple divorce, superannuation is not available in a liquid form to be adjusted between the parties. Even the person who has directly contributed to the fund usually cannot have access to it and may have to wait a number of years before he or she can draw down the superannuation. Added to this is that it can be difficult for superannuation that is the legal property of only one party to a marriage to be adjusted as if it is an asset of both parties to the marriage.

The Family Court may have regard to superannuation as an asset to be taken into account in its calculations and can offset the value of other assets by way of adjustment to compensate the non-superannuated spouse. Such a system is fine if there are sufficient other assets to provide sufficiently for a dependent spouse and children and enough to allow the party with the superannuation to survive until he or she can access that superannuation. Where it falls down, however, is where there are insufficient other assets to allow a fair adjustment to reflect the amount of superannuation involved. It also fails to allow the proper quantification of the superannuation or provide a formula for arriving at a quantification. The reforms will allow far greater clarity in divorce settlements as well as providing certainty for the future of the non-superannuated spouse after a divorce.

There are a number of key areas being examined to guide these reforms through. The first is that superannuation should be clearly recognised in legislation dealing with the division of marital property. The key here is that the principles be clearly defined, not just assumed. The second aspect is that there be clear rules for valuing superannuation that will take into account the vagaries of the different types of schemes. Back of matchbook calculations cause more problems than they solve. By having a defined formula and set of rules, both parties will know exactly where they stand. This is important in order to bring to finality settlement of property and to allow both parties to have a fresh start, especially if new partners and new families are on the scene. The third policy objective with these reforms is to encourage the parties to try to settle their own affairs. To facilitate this, the reforms will ensure that both parties have full information available to them.

On top of this, the reforms will be consistent with the government's retirement incomes policy and arrangements will be made to minimise the complexity and costs for all parties. They will also take into account the particular features of the various types of superannuation funds involved. The government is addressing the tough questions involved with these reforms. One such question is just when will the superannuation be shared between the two parties and in what proportions?

Then there is the question of calculating just how much superannuation will be accrued up to the contributor's retirement. Obviously, if a member of a superannuation fund has been contributing before marriage, an equal division would not be fair. If both parties have superannuation, it may be necessary to offset one against the other to see if any adjustment is warranted. Already the government has written to superannuation industry representatives seeking their input in relation to the reforms. One of the principles in the reforms is to provide maximum flexibility as well as a legislative lever.

There is overseas precedent not only for community of property schemes but also for legislating to ensure superannuation is fairly adjusted on separation. One model is that of British Columbia, with its 1995 Family Relations Amendment Act, which deals with the divisions of superannuation—called `pension' in British Columbia—in the event of a marriage breakdown. This act clearly defines such terms as entitlement, net investment returns, pensionable services and vested pension. The act also details how the calculation of commuted value should be arrived at. This is a vital area which has clouded the division of superannuation in Australia.

Germany and the United States have schemes in place which recognise superannuation as a marital asset. This allows for the equitable division of superannuation as part of the property settlement in divorce proceedings. Great Britain is heading in the same direction. A white paper is being prepared which defines the benefits and tax implications of splitting superannuation, or pensions as they are also called in the UK.

This government is now heading towards the fair division of superannuation. In a marriage breakdown, the prospective loss of benefits on retirement from a former spouse's superannuation scheme can impact with particular severity on the party who was not a member of the scheme and whose potential for loss of security is very great indeed.
The 1994 Australian Law Reform Commission report has pointed out the particular effect on women. It states:
The issue of retirement income is particularly important for women. On average, women live longer than men and are therefore more likely to spend more of their last years alone.

Current government policies are aimed at retirement income being provided by superannuation funded by the employer or the employee, or a combination of both, rather than by government through age pensions.

The problem for women is that the superannuation system is geared to the typical working pattern of a man, not a woman. The greatest benefit is derived by those who work full time and continuously over an extended number of years.
This is not a typical working pattern for women.

Therefore, we have the situation where the non-member spouse loses the prospect of security for the future, the legitimate expectation of which has been a foundation of the financial management of the couple's affairs.

One of the problems faced by the Family Court in trying to determine superannuation entitlements stems from the very nature of superannuation schemes. A common model is the discretionary trust. If the marriage breaks down and the member spouse is not of retirement age, he or she has no proprietary interest in future superannuation entitlements, merely an expectation. How then is the real value of the future benefit to be taken into account in property division given that an order cannot operate directly on the benefit? One technique is what is known as offsetting, under which the Family Court takes future superannuation entitlements into account at the time of property distribution. But the court has experienced considerable difficulty in identifying precisely how the superannuation entitlements should be taken into account and in particular how the entitlement should be calculated at the time of the trial.

Different Family Court rulings such as Prestwitch and Prestwitch, Jenner and Jenner, Webber and Webber and Hauff and Hauff have seen a number of complex formulas being devised. However, there has been no consistency in these formulas. The court has another approach available to it in that it can adjourn part of the family property proceedings if a party's financial circumstances are likely to change significantly in the future—for instance, by benefiting from a superannuation pay-out down the track.

However, this also has its problems. It goes against the grain of the clean break principle in that it may see a case go on for years. Understandably, the courts have tended to prefer the techniques of offsetting rather than adjournment when the spouse with the benefit is a long way off retirement age. Under the current law, these are the only options available as the Family Court stressed in Harrison and Harrison in 1996.

A point of significance in looking at superannuation benefits is that they often involve substantial amounts of money. In a great number of cases, the sum involved is greater than the value of the family home, which so often is the single most valuable asset a couple has. Future superannuation benefits are significant primarily because they affect the financial circumstances of a party after retirement. However, their significance is not confined to future financial circumstances. They also concern past financial circumstances as they constitute enforced savings and, in many circumstances, income which has been voluntarily forgone. Therefore, when a marriage breaks down, a wife may want to make a notional claim on part of her husband's superannuation benefits not only to share in his future economic security but also as compensation for income which her husband earned but did not receive and which she did not enjoy during the marriage.

Some superannuation schemes give members a vested interest in the fund itself, which enables the member to withdraw their contributions plus accrued interest at any time they wish. In these circumstances, the Family Court does not have a problem because clearly there is a present entitlement to property. In other circumstances, members cannot withdraw their funds until retirement and, while there is some authority for the proposition that an entitlement of this kind constitutes property, the prevailing view is that although technically vested it is not property divisible in divorce proceedings.

The third area is funds that do not give members any vested interest in the superannuation fund itself until retirement. In this case members have no rights in respect of the fund, and the court's view is that their superannuation is not regarded as divisible property. In light of the complexity of the issue, private property agreements between parties have assumed some popularity. The Family Law Act makes provision for parties to a marriage to enter into private agreements which, although technically called maintenance agreements, can concern the division of property. Such agreements can be prenuptial, although they are generally entered into upon separation. This is only equitable if the parties are aware they can claim a share of their partner's superannuation.
Commenting on the ignorance of rights and also the problem of identifying superannuation entitlements, the Australian Law Reform Commission noted:

This lack of certainty causes particular hardship for non-contributory spouses, usually female partners, on separation. They do not have a clear basis on which to conduct their negotiations . . . Many are unaware of their entitlement to have superannuation taken into account in property settlement.

As can be seen from the remarks I have made so far, the whole issue of the division of superannuation in divorce cases is murky, confusing and indecisive. This leads to uncertainty of financial future and because the parties often do not understand the complexity of the issues, the debate between the parties so frequently becomes acrimonious.

The government's initiatives will lead to a clear, precise and understandable way to proceed in relation to the division of superannuation. At last there will be equitable and fair division of funds which to many have been a pot of gold largely unavailable to a non-member spouse on divorce. While much of the focus is on protecting women and ensuring that they receive their equitable share of their partner's superannuation, I hasten to say the reforms will cut both ways. If both parties have worked, then both superannuation funds will be accounted for in the divorce settlement, and where, as is increasingly the case, there has been a man who has forgone the economic benefits and stayed at home being a Mr Mum, he will also be protected by the reforms. What could be fairer than that?

talk.start.para: —The Howard government made many commitments on matters rural when it came to office in March 1996. A priority in this long list of promises was the reform of the AQIS meat inspection program—a process that was already well advanced. In August of that year, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) said:

speech.para: The AQIS meat inspection is now the most urgent priority for reform.

I repeat: `the most urgent priority for reform'. The executive director of AQIS told an estimates committee at that time that the project 2 plan was the centrepiece of that reform strategy. The minister announced the start of the government's reforms for the meat inspection program on 1 August 1996. He said that the government was committed to restoring the reputation of AQIS as a professional, efficient and competent organisation. The minister predicted that the reforms would be in place in all export and domestic abattoirs by early 1998—now, in other words.
On 27 February last year, Mr Hickey, the Executive Director of AQIS, told an estimates committee:

We, over a period of 15 to 18 months now, have been developing and submitting proposals for the project to trial Australia's major meat export markets. We have been involved in an extensive round of briefings and discussions with those markets on the principles of project 2, its technical design and the like. The situation we have got to at the moment is that the United States is currently considering the proposal.

In August, I asked Mr Hickey in the estimates process whether projects 1 and 2 were either almost concluded or significantly progressed to conclusion. He answered yes. However, by November significant problems began to emerge. Mr Hickey told the estimates committee on 13 November that the US had advised that project 2 in its current form was not acceptable. He said that the preliminary design work that had been going on in the five plants would continue. He told the committee:

In the interim, we will be having further discussion with the United States authorities to try and pinpoint more precisely the nature of the concerns that they have about the current design of the project . . .
He then identified government verification of the operation as the key issue. He said:
They are matters that I expect will be the subject of discussions between us and our counterparts in the United States in the course of the next couple of weeks.

The minister has been personally involved in this process from the beginning. In July last year, the minister went to the US to discuss his meat reform agenda. He correctly identified the USDA requirement that there be a high level of government scrutiny of the meat industry. For that reason, Mr Anderson put the project 2 plan on the top of his list for talks with the US Secretary of Agriculture, Dan Glickman. Mr Anderson was talking to Dan Glickman again last month. After those discussions, Mr Anderson put out a press release headed `Americans respond positively to government's project 2 meat inspection system'. The first paragraph of that press release stated:
The Australian Government's `Project 2' proposal for company based inspection in export meat establishments has been accepted in principle by the United States authorities.

Mr Anderson said in the statement the breakthrough came in personal discussions with the Secretary of the US Department of Agriculture, Dan Glickman, and members of the US House Agriculture Committee. He said:
I am pleased to say the Americans have charted a path forward for `project 2' . . .

The American authorities reacted with some vigour to this claim, and Mr Anderson was forced to step back from it. Some six days later Mr Anderson—the same person who put out the media release—acknowledged on ABC radio that project 2 in its original form was unacceptable to the Americans.

Mr Anderson was talking to Dan Glickman again last week—this time in Paris. The topic, again, was Mr Anderson's plan for meat inspection. He was interviewed by the ABC last Saturday morning following those discussions. He said he wanted to make two comments. The first was:
We are continuing to negotiate about the best way to do these things in future.
And the second was:
The Americans themselves are looking at hazard based principles for improving quality assurance and food safety.
He went on to say:
There is no difference between us in terms of us agreeing to a sensible and harmonious negotiating process to work it forward.
He said:
That is at this stage the end of the matter.
In other words, he was getting nowhere. He was talking about the process for negotiations rather than the substance of the government's reforms.

Evidence to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee hearings on 26 February confirms this lack of progress absolutely. The committee was told by the Executive Director of AQIS, Mr Paul Hickey, that AQIS was attempting to determine what performance standards would be acceptable to the Americans. The service was also seeking advice on what baseline monitoring and evaluation systems the Americans might accept. Finally, Mr Hickey said that AQIS was attempting to find out exactly what level of federal oversight export meat processing facilities the Americans would find acceptable. This issue was urgent in May 1996, some two years ago. The minister gave it high priority but, according to Mr Anderson, we are now back to square one.

There are two related issues to which the government does need to give priority. The first is the level of support for the industry through subsidies for meat inspection charges until the reform process is complete, and the second is the management of the restructuring of AQIS. The subsidy for export meat inspection charges to allow AQIS to maintain existing services at a reasonable price while it restructured survived the first Howard budget, but it did not survive the second Howard budget. Out went the subsidy, thanks to Mr Costello and Mr Fahey, and up went charges to the industry—some by as much as 200 per cent—or perhaps it was Mr Anderson who proposed to cabinet that support for the meat industry be abandoned. Either way, there was little or no consultation, and the minister was forced to back down.

I have to say that, on the face of it, Mr Anderson's record in cabinet on these matters is not good. Firstly, Mr Anderson must ensure that the level of charges for export meat inspection services is maintained at a reasonable level in 1998-99. The industry does not need another surprise in this year's budget. Secondly, the minister must ensure that AQIS operates within its own rules. For example, the decision to use a company employee as an AQIS inspector at Tongala in Victoria last December has done enormous damage to our reputation in the key markets of the US and the European Union. It does not really matter if the employee only acted for a short time or whether the tasks he performed were basic. AQIS breached its own rules, and the Americans and the European Union took note. We are asking both those countries to accept the lessening of government oversight of the meat processing sector but we then turn around and break the existing rules.

When AQIS was questioned on this matter, Mr Hickey told the estimates committee that it was an administrative oversight. I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to section 75 of the Crimes Act:
Any person who:
(b) falsely represents himself to be a Commonwealth officer, and assumes to do any act or attend in any place for the purpose of doing any act by virtue of pretending to be a Commonwealth officer;
shall be guilty of an offence.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 2 years.

Not only is this sort of action by AQIS politically silly but apparently it is in breach of the Crimes Act. Hence my surprise when the minister supported the use of a company employee in this way. He is now paying the price for AQIS's lack of judgment.

This saga illustrates very clearly two weaknesses in Mr Anderson's management of reforms in the meat industry. He has by no means administered effectively this area of his portfolio, and he has failed to implement change in an area rightly identified by him as a key sector in both the rural and the national economy. By the way, it is an industry that generates $4 billion a year in export earnings and provides thousands of jobs in regional areas. In failing in his duty, Mr Anderson has put at risk the key markets of the USA and the European Union. The minister needs to reconsider his approach, both in terms of the way in which AQIS is now managing meat inspection in this country and what our major markets might reasonably expect from us by way of government oversight. Otherwise, this saga still has a long way to go and, more importantly, the risk to our meat exports will only increase.

I want to refer briefly to the matters addressed by Senator Patterson earlier this afternoon, when she talked about the waterfront and the need for reform on the Australian waterfront. I must say that Senator Patterson's speech was based substantially on hearsay and stories of what might occur rather than on matters of substance. We all hear stories about the lack of performance by the Australian waterfront. Being a senator from Tasmania, I can say we regularly hear in Tasmania that when there is a problem in the delivery of a product it is caused by a strike on the Melbourne waterfront. In fact, that is the excuse that is almost invariably given.

The fact is that I have received that excuse from businesses in Tasmania for the non-supply of a particular product on time even when I personally knew that there were no strikes on the Melbourne waterfront at the time. In other words, the inadequacy of the delivery system or communication or inability of the manufacturer to supply were not the reasons given when, in fact, they were the true reasons. The easy reason given was that there was allegedly a strike on the Melbourne waterfront. So if we are going to deal with this matter, let us deal with the facts and not with innuendo and untrue allegations.

Another matter that Senator Patterson touched upon was the comparison of the Australian waterfront with the waterfront situation in New Zealand. I happen to have received a copy of an article from the Journal of Industrial Relations of September 1997 entitled `Waterfront labour reform in New Zealand: pressures, processes and outcomes'. The author of that is James Reveley, who has a PhD and is a research associate at the Department of Sociology, University of Canterbury. It is a lengthy document but, for the purposes of the exercise, I just want to refer to the conclusion. This is what James Reveley says:

In a comparative article about waterfront reform published in 1992, Turnbull argued that, unlike Britain, Australia had potentially laid the basis for long-term sustainable change. In an update on Britain, it was found that the waterfront industry is currently experiencing a `vicious spiral of cost-competition and ever decreasing margins which is undermining port performance and debasing labour relations.' Notwithstanding differences in port systems, if Australia follows the New Zealand model of waterfront labour reform, which under the Employment Contracts Act is rapidly moving in the direction that employment relations in Britain's ports have taken, this sustainability may well be lost. Far from something to be emulated, the New Zealand experience of waterfront labour reform, like its British counterpart, should be avoided.

In the short space of four years waterfront labour reform in New Zealand moved from attempts by waterfront employers to decentralise bargaining, to the abolition of the Waterfront Industry Commission, through to challenging historic union rights. As a result, the waterfront industry shifted very quickly from union control to employer control, but the imbalances and problems that have occurred are no less numerous or significant than in the 1970s, when the industry was characterised by a dynamic of union strength and employer weakness. Under the Employment Contracts Act the pendulum has now swung too far in the opposite direction, to the point where recent moves by employers to increase labour `flexibility' are threatening to undermine the gains in efficiency that resulted from the abolition of the bureau system.

I commend this article to Senator Patterson and other members of the Senate because, far from being based on innuendo and falsity, it is an analysis of the situation in New Zealand. If we are to compare our situation with the outcome in New Zealand, then we had better know where we are headed.

talk.start.para: —Today I will speak on an exciting matter which again demonstrates the quality of Australian science and engineering and the world-class expertise of Australia's Bureau of Meteorology. Coincidentally, it is also a matter that was reported on in today's Daily Telegraph in an article by environmental reporter Simon Benson.

speech.para: An event recently took place in the skies off the coast of Port Hedland in Western Australia. This event is a wonderful example of necessity being the mother of invention, though in this case it is more a matter of self-preservation because, until now, important weather information being obtained from within a cyclone was an occupation solely for the foolhardy. It involved daring aviators flying expensive aircraft as far into storms as they could physically go in an attempt to gather as much data as they possibly could to help meteorologists get a better understanding of cyclones and therefore improve their ability to forecast them.

So it is with some enthusiasm that I tell you that on Tuesday, 27 January this year, as tropical Cyclone Tiffany was spinning her way down the Western Australian coast, a small gathering of meteorologists and technicians were preparing to launch a small robotic aircraft called an Aerosonde for its first data collecting flight. By all accounts, the mission was a success. So this small aircraft has confirmed its potential as a very useful, low-cost method of gathering and transmitting weather information from remote areas of Australia and its surrounding oceans.

The magnitude of this feat is most definitely of biblical proportions in so far as this small aircraft, with its thin three-metre wing and a distinctive inverted V-tail structure on twin booms, seemed wimpish and no match for a decent thunderstorm—let alone a cyclone like Tiffany, much like a David and Goliath contest. Consider that this Aerosonde has been designed to withstand stresses of up to 15 times the force of gravity. If you compare that with a passenger airliner in flight that is designed to withstand stresses of around five times the force of gravity, that gives you some idea of the conditions inside these cyclones.

This first operational fight was part of a six-week trial that involved eleven Aerosondes in all, which saw a range of missions take off from the Cargill Salt Works outside Port Hedland in north-west Western Australia. The locals call this area Cyclone Alley, and indeed the team were fortunate enough to be able to test this aircraft during that severe tropical Cyclone Tiffany. A significant feature of the aircraft is that while in this case they were being launched and recovered at Port Hedland, the staff working in the Perth Regional Forecasting Centre of the Bureau of Meteorology, some 1,500 kilometres away, were actually the people in control of this aircraft. By this process, forecasters were able to make special requests for observations anywhere within the designated flight region.

The most satisfying aspect of this innovative environmental monitoring concept is that it is being driven by Australians. The Aerosonde is being developed by a Melbourne company, Sencon Environmental Systems, in collaboration with the Bureau of Meteorology. The project leader, Dr Greg Holland, who is from the Bureau of Meteorology Research Centre, has been working for several years on a project to harness converging aeronautical, computing and communications technologies and developing a weather reconnaissance instrument that would economically monitor those huge areas of the southern hemisphere where no direct weather observations exist or, if they do exist, are very rare.

The project has been endorsed by the World Meteorological Organisation and the United Nations International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction and is a result of commendable international collaboration, involving both public and private sectors. Dr Holland's major technical collaborator is a Canadian engineer, Tad McGeer, of Insitu Group Inc. Together they planned an airframe made of carbon fibre and kevlar tough enough to survive inhospitable weather and powered by a 20cc engine. Within this very small air craft they crammed robust, even smaller computers, the emerging technology of global positioning satellite systems and sophisticated communications equipment. They worked out how to enable the aircraft to fly itself under almost infinite options of flight missions, and they drew upon an expanding web of communications satellites to learn how to command the aircraft in flight and how to transmit data continuously and, not least, they learned how to bellyland the l5 kilogram aircraft automatically on the nearest available paddock or bit of flat ground.

Sencon Environmental Services is now assembling production aircraft in Melbourne. It has the potential to be a valuable scientific export for Australia, with more than 30 aircraft already sold to the United States and Taiwan. While the current aircraft are designed primarily for weather reconnaissance, carrying virtually the same radiosondes as are lifted by balloons from 37 Bureau of Meteorology stations around the continent, the Aerosonde is expected to be used in other environmental monitoring tasks as well. For example, it will be able to carry a small video camera or a wide range of chemical or other sensors or perhaps search and rescue operations support.

The model that is being tested at this time will fly for over 30 hours at up to 16,000 feet, if needed—all of this on a 20cc engine. There is essentially no noise or environmental pollution. Recent trials included flights of 31 and 26 hours, with eight daylight flights over seven hours. The research team expects that by the new century the Aerosonde will be able to fly continuously for four days or so with a range of 7,000 kilometres, and it will reach perhaps 45,000 feet with a new turbocharged engine—enough to fly over a cyclone and descend into its relatively calm eye.

Even with today's aircraft, a laptop computer and a mobile phone will enable a scientist in eastern Australia to command the operations of an aircraft monitoring a cold front west of Perth. Indeed, during the recent trials, a test connection via the Internet enabled a scientist at the Bureau of Meteorology Research Centre in Melbourne to assume operational command of an Aerosonde flying north of Port Hedland. That is quite a remarkable feat.

There has been close liaison with the Civil Aviation Safety Authority from the start of this program to ensure that Aerosondes can operate to their full potential while maintaining a high degree of safety and minimal disruptions to large aircraft operations in the area. The meteorological applications are numerous.

As a North Queenslander with some unhappy acquaintance with tropical cyclones, I can see the immediate benefits of something which can remain in the vicinity of dangerous weather systems for days or even penetrate those cyclones. For instance, forecasting cyclone landfalls remains a difficult task, and anything which can capture and relay precise numbers, the pressures, the temperatures, the wind speed and direction from these hazardous systems will make for improved forecasts and a safer community.

You can imagine other targets: pinning down the timing and intensity of a cold front affecting firefighters; tracking a southerly buster whipping up the New South Wales coast; patrolling the data void in the Indian Ocean west of Perth. There is research as well. In late 1995, prototype Aerosondes contributed to international atmospheric research projects, which studied the afternoon thunderstorms which form over the Tiwi Islands north of Darwin before the wet season. Following the Port Hedland operational trials, the weather squadron is to be sent off to another multinational experiment, studying the monsoon life cycle in the South China Sea. Transport is pretty easy: you simply unbolt the wings and the tail assembly and then you carry this aircraft in special suitcases. A scientist can carry an Aerosonde as aircraft luggage.

Aerosondes are expendable, of course. They will be expected to work at times in weather conditions that menace the big planes, and they will do it very well. They will be able to go where humans are unable to. Their complex computing, navigation and communications package complicates the risk but, with a production cost currently below $20,000 each, and at least 20 missions expected from every airframe, they are a monitoring device that merits serious consideration.

I commend the lateral thinking and effort that created these tiny high-tech environmental monitors and the elegant engineering that has provided a robot that flies itself and currently squeezes over 500 kilometres from a litre of fuel. To all of those involved in the design and development of this very special aircraft, I say well done.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Warwick Parer, Minister for Resources and Energy. Is the minister aware of a report in Monday's Financial Review that Australia's minerals and energy exports are under serious threat from the Asian economic crisis? Minister, what has this government done to protect Australia's important minerals and energy exports from serious economic downturn? Is it not a fact that you, as Minister for Resources and Energy, have done absolutely nothing to protect critical Australian industries like coal—industries critical to your home state of Queensland—from the ravages of the financial crisis in the Asian region? What justification can there be for your spokesman to state that the outcome for these industries remains positive?
—I am delighted that at long last I am asked a serious question about what has happened with the Asian fallout, instead of the stupid, nitpicking stuff that usually comes from the other side.

answer.para: As Senator Cook says, the energy and minerals sector is vital to Australia. Our major markets in the Asia-Pacific region are Japan, Korea and Taiwan. Very little of those energy materials goes to the other Asian countries that have been part of the financial meltdown. The country that has suffered most is Korea. I am having continuing discussions with people within the industry. In those discussions, it is their view and mine that one of the major things we have done relates to export controls. I took great exception to Senator Cook saying we have done nothing, and I will list some of the things we have done.

You persisted in keeping export controls over the whole 13 years you were in government. By doing that, you forced those countries to diversify to other countries at the expense of Australia. We got rid of export controls. Countries such as Korea, Japan and Taiwan are now free to purchase more from Australia rather than diversifying between countries. In other words, they can diversify within Australia without the threat of a hostile government holding them hostage in the future. That is an opportunity.

With regard to the Korean situation, the government acted very quickly. I had a number of calls just before Christmas from exporters who were concerned about the fact that banks in Australia were not prepared to accept letters of credit from Korea. We acted very quickly. We increased the EFIC finance by some $300 million. We also added in another $300 million, approximately, in respect of what I think is called public interest, or words to that effect. As I understand it, there is no restriction whatsoever at the moment with regard to the export of coking coal and steaming coal in respect of Korea.

Korea was the country with which we were most concerned. It has been a long-term trading partner of Australia, going back over 20 years to when the first contracts were signed between Australian coking coal companies and Pohang Iron and Steel. I will take you back to those days, Senator. In those days the Korean economy was not that great, but the early suppliers to Korea actually sold their coking coal without letters of credit and on trust. This was very much appreciated by the Koreans, and I know from the discussions I have had in recent times with the Korean purchasers that they are very appreciative of the actions taken by this government in supporting their industry in their time of need.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer the minister to the magnificent work this government has done in turning the $10.3 billion budget deficit inherited from the former Labor government into a surplus, within three years. Could the minister please outline the vast benefits to the Australian community of this strategy. Also, Minister, has the government received support for the strategy in the parliament, and what have been the alternative strategies put forward by the other parties? What would be the implications of such strategies on taxation, interest rates, budget deficit and government debt?

—I thank Senator Gibson for that important question. In this parliament Senator Gibson has always shown a great interest in economic matters, and it is not surprising that he has raised this question.

answer.para: All senators will know of this government's determination to restore fiscal responsibility to the nation's finances. We are determined to take the $10.3 billion deficit inherited from Mr Beazley and transform it into a surplus within this term. Our strategy has helped to cut debt, lower interest rates and build a platform for strong and sustainable growth. It is worth noting that we now have the lowest underlying inflation figures on record and the lowest inflation rates since the late 1960s. Senators will remember that under the failed Labor government interest rates peaked at 17 per cent for some home owners. At present we have one of the fastest growing economies in the developed world. I would have thought that was all good news. Although the Labor Party are complaining about it, people outside are cheering this on, because it is good news.

Sadly, the fiscal responsibility adopted by this government has been opposed in some quarters. The loudest and most vigorous opposition to it has come from the Australian Labor Party. The Labor Party has opposed billions upon billions of dollars worth of budget repair over the four years. On top of that they opposed the very important Telstra saleconstitution

As for promises in recent times, shadow ministers have gone around promising to spend more, all of it uncosted. There are promises, for example, that Mr Beazley made recently in relation to health. Mr Beazley promised to spend another $1.7 billion in that area—unfunded—and, of course, that would have to be costed in to what the Labor Party's policies are for the next election. They have made other promises in relation to foreign-owned nursing homes and indeed—Senator Cook will correct me if I am wrong—R&D syndicates, and Senator Cook was a strong supporter of that area.

talk.start.para: —You are wrong.
—Senator Cook, you opposed this crackdown in this chamber and you were a very strong and vigorous support er of R&D syndicates, and that cannot be denied.
—Absolutely!
—`Absolutely!' he says. Well, we have got that on the record again. A huge tax rort and you support it—that's all right.
—Wouldn't it be good for Australia—
—Thank you for the quote. It is recorded in Hansard , Senator Cook. Thank you for that.

answer.para: As the Treasurer has said on a number of occasions, if people support Labor at the next election interest rates will go back up to where they were under Labor. The Labor Party is a high tax, high deficit, high interest rate party and that was completely shown to be the case during their term in office. Just to illustrate how advantageous our policies are, at the current low level of interest rates the average family is saving some $300 a month or more on an average $100,000 mortgage. Huge savings are being delivered to home owners, and I think they are greatly appreciated by home owners throughout Australia.

One of the things we went to an election on was to avoid the sort of shenanigans we saw under the previous Labor government in relation to hiding the real state of the economy, and, of course, this government has promoted a charter of budget honesty. The truth of the matter is Labor vigorously opposed the charter in this chamber but now they have backflipped. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is it the case, Minister, that you hold shares through your family trust in Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd, or have you disposed of them? Have you ever de clared this shareholding in the register of senators' interests, as you are required to do? Minister, have you complied with the requirement set out by the Registrar of Senators' Interests in his letter of 20 March 1997 that senators should notify actual shares held by relevant family or business trusts on the grounds that `it would not be sufficient to declare only the name, activity and beneficiary of the trust company or partnership'?

—I am pleased to answer the question by Senator Faulkner. I personally have no shares in mining companies. As required in the disclosure rules of the Senate, I have disclosed all interests that I have from a pecuniary point of view. As regards the Prime Minister's requirements, let me say that I have fulfilled all the requirements of the Prime Minister's letter in regard to any investments that I have or that are held by the family trust.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question.
—Order! Senators on my right will cease interjecting. Senator Faulkner, I have not called you yet; I am waiting for the noise on my right to cease. I call Senator Faulkner.

—Thank you, Madam President. Can I ask you again, Senator Parer: have you complied with the requirements set out by the Registrar of Senators' Interests in his letter of 20 March 1997 that senators should notify actual shares held by relevant family or business trusts on the grounds that `it would not be sufficient to declare only the name, activity and beneficiary of the trust company or partnership'? Minister, what, if any, other undeclared shareholdings do you own through your family trust?

—The trust to which Senator Faulkner refers is 28 years old. It is a family trust. I do not control it; in fact, it is controlled by others. It is a discretionary trust which is spelt out in the Register of Senators' Interests and I have one-ninth of that. I have fulfilled, to my best recollection, all the requirements of the Senate in that regard, and that goes back many years. I have never tried to hide anything.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. I refer the minister to the government's goal to protect Australia's unique marine biodiversity, reduce marine pollution and ensure that marine resources are used in an ecologically sustainable way. What action is the government taking to promote off-reserve conservation measures in our vast marine territory? Will the minister indicate how those actions relate to the government's coasts and clean seas program, which is a key feature of the natural heritage program?

—I thank the honourable senator for that important question. It contrasts starkly with the sort of smear questions that we hear from the other side particularly from Senator Faulkner, who has not even got the decency to come in here and apologise to the Baillieu family—to apologise to those Baillieus who are alive and those Baillieus who are dead—just to demonstrate a little bit of basic decency. He might then be better credentialled to ask questions. Anyway, that is by the way.

answer.para: Senator Knowles has raised the important issue of off-reserve preservation of conservation values in Australia's marine environment. It is important because it is another area that has, of course, been neglected in the past, but we now have a responsibility for one of the largest marine territories in the world, an area more than one and a half times Australia's land mass.

One of our goals has been to ensure that our marine environment is protected through a representative system of marine protected areas. Our announcement of a new reserve in the Great Australian Bight, which will be Australia's second largest reserve, is, of course, a down payment on that commitment. But we also recognise that marine parks are not the only answer in protecting marine biodiversity. Just as important will be those measures that we develop off reserve. I am therefore pleased to announce that the Commonwealth has agreed to work with the Western Australian government and the petroleum industry to develop a comprehensive conservation strategy for Commonwealth waters surrounding the Montebello Islands off Western Australia. This is a first. It is an historic development. It is an occasion when an industry organisation will work in partnership with two governments to develop such an important strategy.

At the end of the process we are confident that we will have in place measures that will protect an area of enormous conservation significance, an area that has been identified as providing habitat for a range of marine life, including humpback whales, dugong, turtles and a number of sea and shore birds. So I particularly want to take the opportunity to congratulate the petroleum industry. It is an industry that has itself identified many of these important conservation values within this region and is, as I said, an industry that is prepared to work with government to conserve those values, and for that they deserve to be commended.

I also want to take the opportunity to comment on the coasts and clean seas component of the Natural Heritage Trust. As senators will be aware, the $125 million coasts and clean seas program represents the largest financial commitment by any Commonwealth government to protect our marine and coastal environment. Through that program, we are encouraging innovative solutions to problems such as sewage and stormwater pollution, introduced marine pests, threats to marine species and ad hoc coastal development.

I want particularly to highlight the fact that applications for the 1998-99 round of community grants for the program opened last Saturday. The application period closes on 30 June, after which proposals will be assessed by community based panels before presentation to me. $8.5 million will be available in the year 1998-99 for the community component of the program, and I would encourage senators to ensure that community groups in their areas are aware of the opportunities that the program provides.

I would particularly like to encourage Labor senators, those that have disregarded the opportunity to improve Australia's natural resource base, to improve Australia's natural environment, through the opportunity to support community groups in this way. This is an opportunity for Labor senators to move off the smear path. Perhaps Senator Faulkner could make a start by apologising to the Baillieus, and then opposition senators might commence to do something constructive in this important area of marine environment.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to the Minister for Resources, Senator Parer. Minister, are you aware of clause 14 of the explanatory notes to the statement of registrable interests, which requires senators to publicly disclose:

question.para: . . . any other interest where a conflict of interest with a senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or could be seen to arise.
Minister, did you list under this section—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are too many interjections on my right. It is necessary that I hear the question and it is necessary that Senator Parer hears the question.

—Minister, why did you list under this section matters such as married, ratepayer and Christian but fail to list your significant shareholding in a coalmining company? Is it the case, Minister, that you were going to use the Eastcourt defence that you have previously used?

—I did list those things because I think they are important, perhaps more important when it comes to one's considerations than any other sorts of things that you might talk about. Senator Carr says `listing my shareholdings'. My shareholdings are listed under the Senate register. I think the important thing about this is that we have fairly strict guidelines, as laid down by the Prime Minister. Let me just repeat that I have adhered strictly to those Prime Ministerial guidelines.

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Minister, can you confirm that you still have a shareholding, as listed in the ASC documents, in Queensland Coal Mine Management worth over $2 million, or have you disposed of these shares?
—Madam President, I do not have any shares—

answer.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! It is necessary that the answer be heard. Senators who are talking loudly shall cease. I call Senator Parer.
—I have indicated two or three times that I do not own any shares in mining companies.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Minister, do you agree with the statement made by your colleague Dean Brown, South Australian Liberal Minister for Health, that the federal government has:

question.para: . . . failed to understand the needs and the growing demand of Australians for health care and is ignoring the reality of what is occurring in public hospitals.

Isn't it true, Minister, that this government does not particularly want to understand what is going on in the public system and that you do not care, because what you are planning to do, and indeed what you are doing, is deliberately starving Medicare to death in the hope that people will shift over into the private system? How else can you explain the massive cuts, now in the billions of dollars, that your government has made to the public health system?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Lees for the question. No, I do not agree with Dean Brown's statements because, as you know, Senator Lees, you and I were both around when the previous government was in office when the same charade went on with the states over the Medicare agreements. It is standard practice for the states to come along and demand more money.
—And posture.

—And posture. Thank you, Senator Patterson. This goes on every time. It is a natural progression that occurs, where the states come along and cry that they are poor when in fact in many cases—and I refer to one state—they have boasted how they had cut the amount of funding that went to the public hospitals because of the money that had come from the federal Medicare agreement at the time. You will recall the deals that were done, because you were on the community affairs estimates committee when we considered the previous Medicare agreement.

answer.para: To answer the second part of your question, I would like to read from a statement made by a previous health minister:

As every person pulls out of private health insurance, the profile worsens for those left in. The sick obviously are going to stay in and so the premiums go up. More and more people get pushed out. As they get pushed out, the premiums go up more. It just feeds on itself the whole time, and it is going to come to a crunch point because as they leave private health insurance they are dependent on the public hospital system.
No more, no less than Senator Richardson when he was health minister. I think that if you do not accept my explanation, you will accept his explanation.

Of course there are increased pressures on the public hospital systems of this country. The reason that it occurred is that those opposite left it in tatters and forced people out of private health insurance. As I started to say yesterday, but Senator Forshaw would not let me, 61 per cent were in private health insurance when the Labor Party came into power and by the time they left it was down to about 35 per cent.

Those opposite are responsible for the effects on the public hospital system which were brought about by their de-funding the private health system by removing the bed day subsidy. They gloated about that at the time, how it was going to socialise medicine in Australia because that was the ideal—to have everybody in the public hospital system. But, allied with that, there is something that is not their fault—it is to the credit of the medical profession, as much as anything else in this country—the increasing longevity of people, where two-thirds of the health care expenditure goes on people over the age of 65.

The fact of the matter is that we have got a rapidly ageing population which is causing increased pressures on the public hospital system of this country. We recognise that as a government. In fact, the offer to the states is three per cent over what they had last time, and there is an increase in recognising the difficulties there.

But the reality is that the states have to put money into the public hospital system because it is their responsibility to do so. A fair offer has been made by the federal government to them which they have not accepted—as you know, the previous government went through the same episode before. This happens on every occasion. The states come along crying poor. They come to the federal government, demand funds and say it is the Commonwealth's responsibility, but the reality is that the states have a responsibility in this regard and they have got to devote resources to the public hospitals.

I am delighted to say that in Queensland they are. There is a major rebuilding program going on under the present state government, which is to their great credit. There are new hospitals being built right throughout the state. When the Labor Party was in control, they were deliberately run down and capital expenditure decreased to less than three per cent. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you may accuse the states of posturing, but isn't it the case that you have cut some $700 million out of state grants, $400 million from the public dental health system and $700 million from the PBS—and so it goes on? Isn't it really the case, Minister, that the basic health policy of your government is to starve the public system and to push people into the private and then, if that does not work, to blame the private health insurance system failures?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —That is almost a laughable supplementary question. I would have thought that Senator Lees would have a better understanding of the situation. The public hospital systems and the private hospital systems of this country worked when there was equilibrium—about 50 per cent in either system in my own state. Anybody who was around 20 years ago knew that the system worked very well. Then the Labor Party ran it down by removing bed day subsidies.

answer.para: The Commonwealth government has offered $30 billion, compared with $23 billion paid over the last five years, and $27 billion in the current forward estimates. So it is ridiculous to say that there is less money being offered. There is not less money being offered. We believe, on the other hand, there needs to be a reversal to that equilibrium that occurred before. Anybody who is listening to this broadcast would know that, 20 years ago, there were not the problems that exist today, because the private and the public hospital systems were in equilibrium, and our subsidy was designed to keep people in, to raise the number of people in private health insurance so that they could afford the private hospitals.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, is it true that Investment Management Pty Ltd, IMPL, which is your family trust, holds 16 shares in Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd comprising 1.4 per cent of the 1,111 QCMM shares? Minister, is it further true that you personally own 44 employee shares in the QCMM Group (ESP) Pty Ltd?

—All I can say is exactly what I have said previously—that I have made full disclosure in accordance with the Prime Minister's requirements. I have got to think carefully about this. ESP, as my recollection is—and I stand to be corrected and I will check this—has nothing to do with the mining company itself. It was an employee scheme of some sort that occurred in the days when I was fully involved. I might point out that, on the day I got this appointment—I think within 24 hours; certainly within 48 hours—I resigned from all interests, directorships and chairmanships of that particular company and, I might say, all subsidiary companies. Since that time I have had nothing whatsoever to do with the operation of that particular company.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can I ask you if you have informed the Prime Minister that you have a personal shareholding—
—Order! Senator Parer cannot hear and neither can I. Senators on my right will cease interjecting.

—Minister, have you informed the Prime Minister that you have a personal shareholding in a subsidiary of Queensland Coal Mine Management, called QCMM Group (ESP) Pty Ltd? I might say, you appear not to have disclosed this on the parliamentary register. Wouldn't this mean, Minister, that you would appear to have breached both parliamentary and Prime Ministerial requirements in relation to disclosure of these shareholdings?

—Madam President, I respond again to the Senator. I do not know how often I have to say this. I have exactly fulfilled the Prime Minister's requirements in fully disclosing everything that I own. With regard to ESP, my recollection is that the ESP itself was abandoned some years ago but I will check that. I have no particular recollection of that thing continuing.

—My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice. I refer the minister to the legislation passed in this parliament in relation to the international transfer of prisoners. Could the minister advise the chamber what the status is of the scheme which is being established under this legislation? As there is at least one Australian woman who has been in a Thai prison for well over 10 years, can the minister also advise when it is likely that a bilateral treaty between Australia and Thailand on international transfer of prisoners will be in place?

—I thank Senator Colston for that question. The government is anxious to have the international transfer of prisoners scheme operating as soon as is possible. Following the passage of the Commonwealth International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997 last year the next step is the enactment of complementary legislation by the participating states and territories. Tasmania, Queensland and New South Wales have now enacted such legislation and I am advised that legislation has been introduced into the South Australian parliament.

answer.para: We are also taking preparatory steps to enable Australia to become a party to international agreements for prisoner transfers as soon as is possible. Our first priority is to join the Council of Europe Convention and the Commonwealth scheme. The conclusion of a bilateral transfer agreement with Thailand is also a high priority. But, Senator, I cannot put a date on it. I have no indication of the time span we might need to conclude such agreements. I can assure you that the government remains committed to maintaining cooperation amongst all jurisdictions in participation in the national scheme and, as I say, to working with our first priority, which is the Council of Europe Convention and the Commonwealth scheme. But a high priority is a bilateral transfer agreement with Thailand.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy.
—Order! Senators on my right will cease interjecting.
—Minister, can you confirm that a wholly-owned subsidiary of Queensland Coal Mine Management, a company called Advanced Queensland Resources and Mining—
—Order!

—I might start again for the benefit of the minister so he clearly understands it. Can the minister confirm that a wholly-owned subsidiary of Queensland Coal Mine Management, a company called Advanced Queensland Resources and Mining, operates the Jellinbah Coal Mine in the Bowen Basin in Queensland? Minister, is it also the case that Advanced Queensland Resources and Mining is a significant recipient of the diesel fuel rebate, claiming $1.7 million in 1995-96?

—If anyone cares to look back over the Register of Senators' Interests, and I am sure that that is what you have done, you will find that in the past not only was I on the board of QCMM, in fact I was the chairman of the board. Advanced Queensland Resources and Mining is simply an operating company that is a subsidiary of QCMM. That is correct. If you look back to past years you will find that I put it down there. In fact, when we had to disclose travel I put `travel in association with the company'. It was paid for by the company. From the day that I was appointed as a minister I resigned from that board, I resigned as chairman and I have had nothing whatsoever to do with it since.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has directed himself to the first part of the question but he has said absolutely nothing about the second part of the question. Minister, is it also the case that Advanced Queensland Resources and Mining, which you have indicated you have had a past interest in, is a significant recipient of the diesel fuel rebate, claiming $1.7 million in 1995-96?
—Madam president, I have no idea—

answer.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right will cease interjecting.

—It reminds me of a question that Senator Cook asked once as to whether John Anderson's tractor had diesel in it. I am sure that they use diesel because it is a mining operation. What else do you expect me to answer? Of course they use diesel. I have no idea what they are paid in diesel fuel rebate.

—I direct my question to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the Assistant Treasurer to questions raised yesterday concerning the role of the office of the Minister for Finance and Administration in a letter from Deloitte & Touche staff, which was published in the Australian Financial Review , regarding savings from outsourcing of information technology. Is the minister aware of a response from Deloitte & Touche regarding this matter?

—We have seen a deliberate tactic in this chamber in recent question times where individuals, some of whom are not members of this parliament, are regularly defamed. Senator Faulkner has led that attack. His notorious attack on the Baillieu family remains. The errors having been pointed out to him, he refuses to apologise.

answer.para: I regret to report to the Senate that yesterday Senator Sherry made inferences about Dr Lisle-Williams of Deloitte & Touche in his supplementary question. Dr Lisle-Williams has written to me; he has taken great exception to the question from Senator Sherry. The letter from Dr Lisle-Williams reads as follows:
Dear Senator Kemp,

It has come to my notice that Senator Sherry has implied or suggested that my letter to the Australian Financial Review concerning Commonwealth IT outsourcing resulted from pressure from the Minister for Finance, his office or his officers. This was not the case. I wrote the letter on behalf of my firm in somewhat angry response to the misleading slant and errors of fact contained in the Australian Financial Review article. These errors were acknowledged by the journalist responsible for the article and by the editorial staff in phone discussions.
Dr Lisle-Williams continues:
I take exception to the imputation that I or my firm would yield to ministerial or bureaucratic pressure. The fact is that the article was wrong. Yours sincerely, Michael Lisle-Williams.

I table that letter. There was a serious inference in the question regarding Dr Lisle-Williams. I trust that Senator Sherry will now do the right thing and appropriately apologise to Dr Lisle-Williams.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to Senator Parer on the same subject.
—Order! Senators on my right should observe the provisions of standing order 197 and refrain from speaking while another senator has the call.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I respect that you can call whomever you want, but when Senator Ray was given the call he was actually stand ing behind Senator West. Is it appropriate for Senator Ray to seek the call while he is wandering around the chamber, sitting in the advisers box or speaking to Senator Faulkner? Or should senators stand in their place and seek the call?

—The custom for question time has become that I follow a list that I am provided with. There are many senators who do not stand up when they should; they wait till they are called to even stand. Senator Ray was standing at the time, though not quite in his place.
—Madam President, on the point of order: I do not regard a senator waddling along the back row as standing. It was a waddle, not a stand.
—You are out of order, Senator Campbell.

—My question is directed to Senator Parer. Minister, could you explain why the ASC company returns for Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd showed that as of 30 January 1998 your family trust owned 16 shares in that company and also listed an address which I think you would know very well—I do not want to put the address on the record at the moment, Senator. Can you confirm that this company's asset value is $153 million? Can you confirm that the shares that your family trust holds are 16 C class shares? Are you now willing to say on the record whether these shares have derived very substantial income into your family trust, of which you are a beneficiary?
—I pointed out earlier that this family trust has been in existence for 28 years.
—But you were present, Warwick, at the meeting.

—Let me continue. I point out that I have a one-ninth interest and that it is a genuine family trust—it is not a tax lurk or anything like that. It goes back 28 years. I certainly do not recall in the past 10 years ever getting a dividend or a distribution from that particular family trust. We have a large family of seven children, and that is what it is—a trust. I confirm—I do not move away from it; this information certainly has been given to the Prime Minister as required—that the shares in that company are 16 non-voting shares.

answer.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of interjection is unacceptably high, as it has been on days recently, and totally out of order as far as the standing orders of this Senate are concerned. An interjection from time to time that is witty may add to the ambience of Senate question time and is acceptable, an intelligent interjection may also be acceptable, but the sledging, shouting and screeching that goes on is not acceptable. Senators should be warned that I have drawn the standing orders to their attention.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, I refer to your review of the Commonwealth environment legislation. Yesterday you twice avoided answering a simple question about regulations on world heritage areas, so today I will make it a little easier for you. The Commonwealth lists three invertebrates, 19 fish— Government senators interjecting —
—Order! Senators on my right will cease making so much noise. It is important that I hear the question that is being asked.

—The Commonwealth lists three invertebrates, 19 fish, 14 amphibians, 52 reptiles, 82 birds, 49 mammals and 886 plants as rare or endangered. Minister, in abolishing the Endangered Species Act, will you give a commitment in this chamber to the Australian people that you will relist every one of these rare or endangered species under your new legislation?

—Of course I will. We were advised on which species to list by an independent scientific subcommittee. The point that I regret that you are failing to appreciate, Senator, is that the purpose of this legislation is to update and improve what currently exists, which is now very outdated. In the case of biodiversity protection, it does not exist at all. It is time that the Common wealth's environment laws were brought up to best practice.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I did not ask about whether or not the legislation needed to be updated; I asked whether the minister would guarantee that those rare or endangered species would be protected. It is a simple question to which the answer is yes or no.
—I think the minister is dealing with the question as asked, and I would say there is no point of order.
