—I thought I started answering the question by saying yes, they will be protected. But the point I was going on to make is that they will be better protected under the new legislation than they are under the old. If Senator Allison reads the consultation paper in relation to endangered species—
—That's our worry; we have.

—If she reads it in relation to endangered species, she will see exactly why that is so. I will ask Senator Lees, who has interjected, whether a threat to endangered species on state land at the moment triggers the Commonwealth protective mechanisms under the ESP Act. The answer is it does not. At the moment it does not on non-Commonwealth land. Under the new legislation it will. I do not mind taking some further Commonwealth powers to protect the most valuable of our national natural resources. I will do that through a scheme that will provide a better mix of roles and responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the states. The outcome will be a more effective, contemporary, protective arrangement to protect these great resources. Whether it is world heritage areas, they will continue to be protected more effectively than they are at present.

answer.para: As I said yesterday—and you have gone on about it again today, Senator; you did not listen—there will be no damming of the Franklin, there will be no logging within the wet tropics area. Not only will world heritage be protected to the extent it is under current legislation; it will be more effectively protected. That is our objective, and we are quite proud of it. I do not understand why you are opposed to it.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. We are vaguely reassured but I must say that the problem here is that the minister has put out the most vague discussion paper possible on this and it is very difficult for the public to understand what the intention is. Again, I ask: will these endangered species be listed in the schedule? That is the important point. So far we have heard much about responsibility being transferred to the states but the point here is whether those species will be listed.

—They will be listed. They will continue to be protected on Commonwealth land as they are under the existing legislation, and they will be further protected because the Commonwealth will take a wider responsibility in relation to those endangered species, no matter where they are.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Federal Republic of Germany led by Mr Klaus Hasenfratz. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the chamber and wish you a pleasant and enjoyable stay in this country.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, is it a fact that the Howard government last year announced a $3.6 million funding cut to the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation? Can you confirm whether fishing is the only primary industry to have had funding cuts to its R&D corporation?
—Didn't you hear that?
—Order! Senator Vanstone. Senator Murphy, have you finished the question?

—No, I want to add a little more to the question. I thought I might find something about shares in here. Minister, given that recent reports have supported an increase in research into fisheries, how do you justify this cut taking effect as it does in 1998—the Year of the Oceans?
—Madam President—
—Declare an interest.

—Yes. This was very much canvassed in an estimates committee, but let me point out the background to it. Yes, there was a $3.6 million cut and it came from reserves held by the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation. The background to it is that, when we came to government, we inherited a total disaster in the south-east fisheries—something that the last government should be totally ashamed of. There was litigation after litigation by people who had been unfairly dealt with by the previous government. The only way to handle this was to go into a buy-out scheme, so I appointed a special committee to look at a buy-out scheme so that those people who had been unfairly treated could be given the chance to sell their licences. Compensation was paid in certain cases.

answer.para: An estimate was made and, if my memory is correct, about $6.9 million was required. We had to find the funds. It is difficult to find funds when you come into government and you need to do something like this but you have a $10.5 billion black hole left to you as a legacy of the mismanagement of the previous government.

Two sources were found. Part of the moneys was obtained from AFMA, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, from a fund that they had set aside for adjustment, but there was not sufficient funds to be able to do that. The rest we sought and it was obtained from reserves that had been built up by the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation. We naturally would have preferred not to have taken that route, but the priority was to fix up a disaster left to us by the previous government and, because of the stringent financial conditions at the time, this was the only way it could be done.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. In light of today's release of the final report of the National Competition Councils's review of the Australian Postal Corporation Act, I ask: is it true that the government is committed to increasing competition in the postal sector whilst adhering to the coalition's election commitments to retain Australia Post in full public ownership and to maintain a standard letter service for all Australians at a uniform rate? Further, is the minister aware of any alternative proposals or approaches to postal services? Are these alternatives being given serious consideration by the government?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I welcome the release of the report from the National Competition Council. It is a review that has taken many months to prepare. It certainly reflects the extensive consultation process that has been undertaken. I personally thank Graeme Samuel and his fellow counsellors and staff for the work that has been put into the preparation of this comprehensive report.
—Another little mate!

—What about Skase's little mate? That is what you should be more concerned about. The government will develop a comprehensive response to the NCC recommendations in the next few months. But, as Senator O'Chee rightly says, any response will fully honour the coalition's election commitments—namely, that Australia Post will be retained in full public ownership and that the entire nation, including those in rural and regional Australia, will receive a standard letter service at a uniform rate.

answer.para: At the same time, we are committed to increased competition in the postal services sector which, in every other area of human endeavour, normally leads not only to greater efficiencies but also to price reductions. There is no reason why that cannot occur in this industry as long as the proper community safeguards are in place. Of course, that is very good news for consumers. It is also the fact that with new technology developments, particularly the Internet, there is going to be constant competition for Australia Post and other postal providers in any event. They will clearly continue to be under increasing pressure to deliver faster, cheaper and higher quality services for consumers.

So we have a clear position. We are committed to reforms, but sensible ones that reflect the paramount concerns of users of the service, consumers in general. By contrast, the Labor Party is once again all over the shop. If you look at the Australian Financial Review in October last year, you will see Senator Schacht claiming that no case had been made to change the current rules. The ALP did not see any reason to change the current arrangements. He said that before this discussion paper was even released—at the very start of the process. In other words, he could not be bothered addressing himself to any of the policy issues.

Senator Schacht's idea of serious policy formulation is to wander down to Manuka on a Friday afternoon and have a nice, long, leisurely lunch with the Jim Middletons, the Peter Cole-Adamses and all the other members of the club who congregate there on a regular basis. We do not regard that as a substitute for policy formulation. This bloke can hardly put a word on paper. He certainly cannot put anything on his web site, we know that. He cannot ever address any submissions to inquiries.

Now it is quite clear, from what happened in Hobart, that he has no idea in terms of policy reform in this important area. You do not have to take my word for it. Simon Crean, the industry spokesman, in September 1996 said that you can never rule anything out site unseen. He obviously did not know Senator Schacht's form. He said, `If you retain a community service obligation, it is possible to open up to more competition as long as you are guaranteeing the service.' So there is the Simon Crean position in relation to Australia Post.

The alternative, which presumably is still espoused by the ALP and its official spokesman, the leader of the faction for disgruntled unionists, is one that simply says, `I can't be bothered. I'm not interested. I'm going to bury my head in the sand. I'm going to try to get through this election with the sort of dirt and scum that we have had thrown up to distract attention from Senator Bolkus's unprecedented censure in this place.' In almost 30 years we have not had a senator censured; yet this person has been censured by everyone who was in here, except his mates, who felt they had no choice but to support him. That is not our approach.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, are you aware that in your home state of Queensland Minister Anderson has funded the following projects under the Natural Heritage Trust: $63,350 for a project officer for the northern dairy industry; $70,000 for the fruit and vegetable industry future profit project; $112,800 for eight workshops entitled `Planning a future in beef—North Queensland'; and $10,500 for office accommodation for the Hodgson Creek catchment project officer? Minister, can you tell the Senate exactly how projects such as these meet the Natural Heritage Trust objective of `a better environment for Australia in the 21st century'?

—As Senator McKiernan will know, before agreements are reached on the funding of various projects in the various states, they have to go through a regional assessment process and a state assessment process. They then come to the minister. What Senator McKiernan is raising, I think, is yet again the issue of accountability, which Senator Hill was pursued on at great length.

answer.para: The minister, Mr Anderson, has worked hard to ensure that accountability is built in at all levels of the trust's activities. The Natural Heritage Trust provides a repository for funds and a mechanism to coordinate delivery of a range of nature conservation and sustainable agricultural initiatives. I think the very issues that you touched on—I did not pick them up; I do not know them individually—relate to agricultural industries. The details of these initiatives were set out in the government's election commitment documents and the Natural Heritage Trust application guidelines.

As I mentioned earlier in reference to what they call RAPs and SAPs, project assessment is a rigorous process which demonstrates the strict standards of accountability built into the trust. The applications were received in all states and territories, not just Queensland, and assessed by the community and state assessment panels. Each state then forwarded a prioritised bid to the Commonwealth. Recommendations made by the panels provided the basis for decisions on project funding made by Ministers Hill and Anderson.

There is not much I can add to that. That is the process that is gone through. As far as I am aware, apart from questions raised by people opposite, there has not been any complaints from my home state of Queensland.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, thank you for your answer, as far as it went. But you, Minister, would also be aware that the Prime Minister has guaranteed that the Natural Heritage Trust would be used for capital expenditure and not for recurrent purposes. How can you and Minister Anderson justify NHT grants going to pay for office accommodation?

—In response to Senator McKiernan, the detail of that I will refer to Minister Anderson, but my understanding is that it has gone through all the very strict processes involved with the Natural Heritage Trust, from the regional assessment programs, the state assessment programs and then back through the ministerial office. But I will refer that specific request to the minister and get you an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I refer to Senator O'Brien's allegations in the chamber on Monday that a Queensland company, Allhands Hire Pty Ltd, was selected to provide employment services when it had financial problems with unprofitable contracts and was put up for sale only days after DEETYA informed the company of its success in the tender process. Can the minister shed any light on Senator O'Brien's allegations?

—Thank you for that question, Senator Tierney. Senators will recall that the day before last Senator O'Brien asked a question about Allhands Hire Pty Ltd. The allegation was that that company was going to be sold and that there was some financial difficulty thereby and also casting doubt on the government's Job Network process. Let me tell the Senate that that company is not for sale.
—Was it for sale?
—As a result of that, it has lost two clients.
—Was it for sale?
—I have been advised that that company has lost two clients.
—Was it for sale?
—Senator Evans!
—It is not for sale.
—Was it?
—Senator Evans!

—A member of the family who contacted the department today has said that approaches were made to the company for the sale of it and that there was no aspect of it being sold. This is a smear tactic to cast doubt on Job Network. More importantly, it has damaged a citizen. It has damaged a private entity which does not have the ability to reply. It does not have the protection that we in this chamber have. As a result of that, it has lost two clients. That is despicable.

answer.para: As I stated the other day, the opposition must be very careful before it makes these sorts of allegations. It must get its facts straight. It was reported yesterday in the Sydney Morning Herald that this business was not for sale. It is an experienced business in the employment sector, and it has a lot to offer those job seekers. It is a respectable business and there is no problem with it.

Let me also tell the Senate that the process that we have put in place requires that, if any business is sold, if any Job Network member intends to sell its business, it has to go back to the department for vetting. It has to go back to the department for vetting so that you cannot just on sell your business and the contract goes to someone else. It has to go back to the rigorous process that it went through when the tender was granted.

This is a usual tactic. When the government puts forward something constructive for the job seekers of Australia, we have a smear tactic which not only causes scaremongering amongst job seekers but also damages a private Australian, an Australian who does not have the ability to answer that allegation like we have in this chamber. It is despicable. You want to cast your minds back to when employment was at an all time high under your government of 11 per cent and see what you did for job seekers then. Nothing. Look at what we are doing: we are offering job seekers more diversity and more choice, and you should apologise.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, was Senator O'Brien's wildly inaccurate allegations against a reputable company just part of a pointless trawl by the ALP through the Job Network tender process that wasted two days of the Senate's time last week and revealed nothing? Would the minister care to compare the success of this program with Labor's failed Working Nation program?

—I thank Senator Tierney for his supplementary question. As we all know, Working Nation was a $12 billion disaster. It was a training roundabout which just put people back into training. It did not find people jobs. What we have embarked on here with Job Network is a tendering process to find the best people to match people for the jobs concerned. What we are doing here is providing a choice between those private providers and Employment National, and we are providing a variety of services from job matching to intensive training for those disadvantaged job seekers.

answer.para: This is an innovative scheme which will answer the needs of Australian job seekers. The opposition fails to remember that, when their current leader was minister for employment, long-term unemployed increased by 95,000. That is what they want to think of before they attack Job Network. This is a process which will meet the needs of Australian job seekers, one which they could never have thought of. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Yesterday in question time Senator Quirke asked me a question with regard to the spending of $25,328 for the sod-turning ceremony at the AGSO building. He then went on to ask a number of other questions, such as, was there an open tender process and how could I justify paying this ludicrous amount of money for a sod-turning ceremony without testing the market. When he referred in his question to the fact that this had been something that Senator Faulkner raised, he should have been on his guard. You always have to be careful of the Left. My reason for saying that is that this contract with Burson-Marstellar was given under the term of the previous government.
—Ha, ha!

—I have here a letter written on 15 January 1996 where Burson-Marstellar were advised that they were successful and that they should spend no more than $25,000 depending on the cost of printing the kits.

speech.para: The other question raised is in respect of a shovel. I think Senator Faulkner asked me whether I had declared it. So I thought had I better check as to what the cost of this shovel was. It was apparently bought at the local BCC Hardware, taken out for chrome plating, and has a total cost of $110.

One of the concerns I had was what to do with this shovel. I thought to myself that probably a more appropriate use of the shovel would be if I gave it to Senator Quirke; he could use it to clean the bulldust out of this place that we are used to from day to day. Another thing he could do would be to use it in an appropriate way to get back at Senator Faulkner for giving him a question where, as pointed out in a headline in the Daily Telegraph today, it says `Sod it, it happened under us'.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Forshaw asked me a question yesterday about the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and outsourcing. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

Senator FORSHAW—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, are you aware of the impending corporatisation of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and the resulting system of competitive tendering for CRS's role of rehabilitation and return to work for injured and disabled workers?Minister, are you also aware that staff, clients and community groups are seriously concerned about this outsourcing having the effect of denying seriously injured or disabled workers any access to a service at all, either to the CRS or a private agency, because the priority criteria for tendering will be the cost of provision and the likelihood of an early return to the workplace? Is this not just another example of the government abandoning its responsibilities to another disadvantaged group in the labour market and, accordingly, another that the government should be condemned for?

Senator FORSHAW—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Whilst, Minister, you can go away and update yourself on your portfolio responsibilities in this chamber with respect to rehabilitation services, I would also like you to answer this supplementary question. Minister, isn't it the case the corporatisation of CRS and the outsourcing of work undertaken by CRS until now will also have the effect of denying injured and disabled clients any protection of their rights through the Privacy Act, the Freedom Information Act and the rest of the administrative law system? Won't these actions of the government leave these workers even more vulnerable and unable to exercise rights that they have been able to exercise up until now?
Senator HERRON—In response to the question asked on 10 March 1998 by Senator FORSHAW, the Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer:
"The Minister for Family Services announced in a media release on 22 December 1997:
* the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) will separate from the Department of Health and Family Services on 30 June 1998;

* the Government's intention to introduce competition for provision of Commonwealth funded rehabilitation services to give people with an injury or disability choice of provider for the first time, and best possible value from the Government's substantial investment in rehabilitation services;
* the government's intention to consult with both industry and consumer groups on how best to introduce such competition.

Transitional legislation will be introduced into the Parliament in this Sittings to facilitate establishment of CRS as a Commonwealth owned company which, pending introduction of competition, will operate under a contract to the Department of Health and Family Services, which will continue to be subject to administrative law requirements. No Government decision has been made on how competition will be introduced and won't be until there has been an opportunity to consult with industry and the community. No decision has been made to introduce competitive tendering for rehabilitation services and this is only one among a number of ways of introducing competition.
Accordingly the Honourable Senator's questions on outsourcing and competitive tendering are misdirected.

The Government is interested in achieving the best possible outcomes for people with an injury or disability. Eligible persons rights to Commonwealth funded rehabilitation services will be maintained under these reforms."

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees asked a question of me in my capacity representing the Attorney-General a few days ago, and I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard his answer.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

Senator Vanstone: On Monday 9 March 1998 Senator Lees asked me a supplementary question in my capacity as Minister representing the Attorney General about legal advice provided to the Government on the operation of s.57 of the Constitution and the Native Title Amendment Bill.
Her 2 questions to the Attorney-General were:
(1) Whether any minister sought a formal legal opinion from him or his Department? and
(2) Whether or not this advice was delivered before the House of Representatives laid the original bill aside.
I undertook to refer the matter to the Attorney General who has provided me with the following response:
The Government did obtain legal advice on the operation of section 57 and its implications for the Native Title Amendment Bill.
That advice was provided prior to the House resolving to lay the Bill aside.
The Government completely repudiates any suggestion by Senator Lees that there is any notion of a "dodgy joint sitting" in relation to the Government's actions in relation to this Bill.

I note that the Government' s legal advice has been independently affirmed by George Williams—an ANU Law Faculty Constitutional Law expert. In a research note for the parliamentary Information & Research Services titled "The Road to a Double Dissolution?", Mr Williams states:

"On 6 December 1997 the House of Representatives indicated that it would not agree to many of the Senate amendments and laid the Bill aside. This meets the requirement in s.57 that the Bill be passed by the Senate `with amendments to which the House of Representatives will not agree"'.

"However, in the opinion of the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, s57 has not been complied with. He argues that `there must be an ongoing unwillingness by the House of Representatives to accept amendments made by the Senate' . . . .

"However, in the opinion of the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, s57 has not been complied with. He argues that `there must be an ongoing unwillingness by the House of Representatives to accept amendments made by the Senate' . . . .
Mr Williams then goes on to state

"This interpretation may, as Evans argues, be supported by `the procedures of both Houses'. However, it is not supported by the text of the Constitution. Evans places too much weight on the words `will not agree' in s.57 to find that it is mandatory that the Bill be returned to the Senate after the House of Representatives has rejected the Senate amendments. The Constitution merely requires that the Bill be passed by the Senate `with amendments to which the House of Representatives will not agree'. The extra step set out by Evans goes beyond the demands of the Constitution. It is also not necessary in order to maintain the Senate's role in the lawmaking process."

Mr Williams article completely supports the position taken by the Government on the true interpretation of section 57 of the Constitution. The Government has always been careful to ensure that it is acting within the clear scope of the processes provided for by the Constitution for resolving deadlocks. It will continue to do so and, as appropriate, seek legal advice as required.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Collins asked a supplementary question of me again in my capacity representing the Attorney-General. I undertook to get an answer from the Attorney-General, and I seek to incorporate that in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

Senator VANSTONE : On Tuesday 10 March 1998 Senator Jacinta COLLINS asked me a supplementary question, in my capacity as Minister representing the Attorney-General, about comments made by the Administrative Review Council about the contracting out of services.

I undertook to refer the matter to the Attorney-General and to provide an answer at a later time. I am now able to table a response to the supplementary question asked by Senator COLLINS. The information has already been provided to Senator Jacinta COLLINS.

para.inline: FURTHER RESPONSE TO SUPPLEMENTARY QUESTION BY SENATOR JACINTA COLLINS ON 10 MARCH 1998

speech.para: Senator Vanstone:

Senator Collins implied that the Administrative Review Council has formed a final view on issues of accountability and contracting out. The ARC has not yet issued a final report on Contracting Out but it issued an Issues Paper in February l 997 and a Discussion Paper in December 1997. Both docu ments predated the Government's announcement on proposed amendments to the FOI Act and, therefore, do not take it into account.

Accountability to the public will be maintained in the process of Government outsourcing. The Government's strong commitment to this is demonstrated by its already announced decision that the Freedom of Information Act will apply to requests by individuals for access to and correction of personal information about themselves held by contractors on behalf of the Government. Government agencies will ultimately be accountable for compliance with obligations imposed by the Act.

Access to information in the hands of contractors will still also be available through contractual provisions under which a government agency has a right of access to documents held by a contractor. The Government intends that there will be minor clarifying amendments to the FOI Act which will ensure that access can be sought under the FOI Act where there are such contractual rights of access.
The ARC' s final report on Contracting Out is also expected to canvass issues of access to administrative review in respect of contracted service provision.

The committee has investigated the matter and reported to the Senate in accordance with the order of the Senate of 20 June 1996, relating to the unauthorised disclosure of committee proceedings and documents. The committee has reported, in accordance with that order, that the unauthorised disclosure caused damage to the committee's work.

interjection.para: The matter clearly meets criteria which I am required to consider. I therefore determine that a motion to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence. I table the letter from the committee. A senator on behalf of the committee may now give a notice of motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee.

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:
The unauthorised disclosure of a draft report of the Economic References Committee referred to in the report by the committee of 10 March 1998.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of answers given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the financial interest of Senator Parer.

Today the opposition has raised a number of questions regarding very serious matters—questions that we believe it is appropriate for the Minister for Resources and Energy to answer comprehensively on the public record. We now, of course, have a situation where apparently the government believes that it is not appropriate for the opposition to hold the executive accountable during question time. We will not be adopting that level of ministerial and parliamentary accountability when, as we have a situation here, we have been provided with information—

talk.start.para: —Have you been at the ASC again looking up dead directors?
—Order! Senator Campbell, it is disorderly to interject, in the first place; but it is even more disorderly to interject out of your seat.

—When we have information that indicates that discrepancies exist between the minister's own statements, his entries on the Register of Senators' Inter ests and publicly available Australian Securities Commission companies information.
—He is very good at looking up dead directors.
—Order!

—We believe it is appropriate that the minister set the record straight on these issues. We invite the minister to provide answers to a number of questions, and they are important ones. Senator Parer ought to address himself to the issue of whether his Register of Senators' Interests lists all shares.
—You found your way down there!
—Order! Senator Campbell. Senator Faulkner, excuse me.
—Take your seat.
—You are not sitting down either, grub.
—Yes, I am.

—Order! Senator Ray. It is not appropriate to interject in this place at any stage, and it is more inappropriate to interject when you are not in your seat. I would please urge you to observing standing orders and to cease your interjections. Thank you.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. We ask Senator Parer: does your Register of Senators' Interests list all shares held either directly or indirectly by your family trust? If not, why not?
—When is the next meeting of dead directors?
—We ask Senator Parer: does your register of interests identify your apparent interest in a coal-mining company as a potential conflict of interest; and, if not, why not?
—Why don't you apologise, you scumbag?
—Order! Senator Campbell.
—When is the next meeting of dead directors?
—Order! Senator Campbell.

—We ask: have you divested yourself of all shares in the area of your portfolio responsibility; and, if not, why not? We ask Senator Parer: is your directorship of a trust which holds mining shares likely to conflict with your public duty? We ask Senator Parer—
—We ask you to apologise.

—We ask Senator Parer: do your business interests expose you to charges of using public office for private gain? We ask Senator Parer, in relation to the details of his family trust—and we know that it owns the shares in QCMM from third party sources—what else does it do?
—We ask: when are you going to apologise, you scumbag?

—We ask: is it, or its related entities, engaged in activities related to Senator Parer's ministerial responsibilities? We ask: where does it get its income? We ask: does it have the power to influence, directly or indirectly, any other company?

speech.para: The opposition is asking for substantive answers to what we believe are very important questions, because we are well aware of the requirements incumbent on ministers regarding their public duties and private interests. For example, there is the statement of registrable interests which says that:

Any senator must notify any relevant interest in any shares which enables the senator, the senator's spouse or dependent children to exercise control over the right to dispose of those shares. This includes shares held by a family or business trust.
The notes also state:
The senator must list any other interest which in the opinion of the senator holds the potential for real or apparent conflict of interest with the senator's public duties to arise.

We ask about the discredited Prime Minister's guidelines on ministerial conduct. We just say that the Prosser defence, that is, `I have complied with all requirements', is not good enough. This minister must be accountable on these important issues.

talk.start.para: —Another grubby attack from the gutter by the Labor Party. Regrettably, the attack is a smokescreen to try to hide the absolute inconsistencies and the smearing by the Labor Party in this chamber of the parliament.

speech.para: But the distressing thing is that the Labor Party choses to attack one of the ablest ministers of the Howard government, Senator Parer. Senator Parer has devoted his life to Australia and has created something of real wealth for this country. He has done something which employs hundreds of workers in the coalmines and elsewhere and he is a very great Australian. The Labor Party choses to attack and smear this man, just as they always do.

We thank Senator Richardson for his book, Whatever It Takes. He told us how the Labor Party, when they are in trouble and want to attack a competent person, brings out the smears and lies to do it. That is what has been happening today.

talk.start.para: —You should hear what he says about John Faulkner.

—I know what he says about John Faulkner, but he does not take much notice of Faulkner and neither does anyone else. It is the old Labor Party, union, bully-boy stuff to attack one of the ablest ministers.

speech.para: It is a smokescreen to hide the censure of the would-be first officer of this nation, Senator Bolkus, from those very serious charges of which he has been found guilty; not just in this chamber and not just in the other chamber, but in both chambers. They know that this is a rare and very serious thing and they will smear and tell lies to try to hide that from tomorrow's media.

It is also a smokescreen to try to hide the ineffectual leadership that the Labor Party has in this chamber. We all know how Senator Faulkner and Senator Cook got their jobs here. It is without question that Senator Ray—for all his faults—is the real leader of the Labor Party in this chamber and should be on the frontbench. Senator Faulkner and Senator Cook got their jobs because the Labor Party has to share the factional jobs around. In the other chamber Mr Beazley happened to be elected as leader and Mr Evans happened to be elected deputy leader and they were both from the Right.

You would know, Madam Deputy President, as everybody over there does, that they had to give the Centre Left and the Left a job. What did they do? They put the most able, Senator Ray, up in the back row—and Senator Ray acquiesced in this because he knows the deal—and they put some dummy from the Left at the main table and some guy from the Centre Left who was the second choice behind him. That is how we get this weak ineffective leadership in this chamber.

The Labor Party will smear and tell lies about Senator Parer and anyone else to try to hide this lack of leadership. It is also a smokescreen to hide the ineffectiveness and absolute lack of any intestinal fortitude of Mr Beazley as the Leader of the Labor Party. Can you imagine what would have happened in this very hypothetical instance if Mr Howard had been Leader of the Labor Party over the last week? Senator Bolkus would not have lasted five minutes, because Mr Howard would not have anyone on his frontbench who deliberately leaked a stolen document and distributed it to the world just so that Mr Skase—that criminal who used to be in Australia—could escape retribution. Senator Bolkus has released that information so that a criminal, Mr Skase, can escape.

talk.start.para: —Why did he do that?

—Senator Calvert might well ask, `Why did he do that?' Mr Beazley's leadership is what tells. Everybody knows that Senator Bolkus will never, ever be the first law officer of the land. There is not a person sitting opposite who would argue with that. What it shows is that Mr Beazley simply cannot control his troops. He would like to get rid of Bolkus, but he cannot stand up to the Left and Centre Left of his party.

speech.para: Also, Mr Beazley is showing lack of any leadership in the way he has dealt with the Oxley preselection. There is a woman who wants to get up there and the national exec utive of the Labor Party has threatened to tip a bucket over her so she will be put out of the race. Where is Mr Beazley coming into this? He should show some leadership and stop the ALP from threatening to tip a bucket over this woman. You would understand, Madam Deputy President, that the women are supposed to have 35 per cent of the safe seats in the Labor Party. Where is Mr Beazley's leadership? This whole attack is a smokescreen to hide Mr Beazley's inefficiencies. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The questions asked of Senator Parer today do require an answer—maybe not immediately because there were some complex questions asked and we will certainly give Senator Parer time to answer them. It did appear from some of the questions today that he either was confused at the type of questions that went to him, or on a couple of occasions said that he was having some difficulty with his memory in this particular area. We await him going back, going through the records and giving us answers to those particular questions that he could not quite focus on today. But the one thing he consistently said was, `I have complied with the Prime Ministerial guidelines.'

speech.para: We do not know whether to challenge that totally or not because we do not see the declaration Senator Parer makes to the Prime Minister. What we do see is the declaration that Senator Parer makes to this chamber and to the public as a whole through the parliamentary process of disclosure. That is on the record, not only in its basic text but also in any amendments made over the last four years. We see that. But if Senator Parer has accurately stated all of his interests to the Prime Minister and it is not reflected in his pecuniary interest form in the Senate, then it reflects badly not only on him but even more so on the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, to whom the Prime Minister himself has said he entrusted the task of checking it all carefully. Surely he would have compared the Prime Ministerial declaration form with the Senate one to see if there were any inconsistencies.

While I am on the Senate one, I still have this problem with Senator Parer: he lists a company, as I understand it, that controls his family trust. I do not think he ever actually goes to the point of declaring his family trust, but that could have been an oversight or a belief that, by putting the organising company in there, that would be good enough in terms of declaration.

We did have a letter go out some time in March 1997, following some controversy, asking people if they owned family trusts that had substantial shareholdings and to put some more detail on the record. Senator Parer has made no such amendment. But the thing that really confused me today was when Senator Parer said, `I think some of these things may have happened more than 10 years ago.' The basic thrust of our questioning, in terms of owning shares that may have a benefit in coalmining, is that this was set up in 1994—just four years ago. I would have thought Senator Parer would have remembered this arrangement for these 16 C class shares. For anyone thinking that 16 shares is not much, there are only just beyond 1,100 shares in totality for a company that values its own assets at $153 million—so we are not talking about peanuts.

Apparently he cannot focus on and remember the allocation of those shares in 1994. I will tell you why I am even a little more shocked by that: guess who chaired the meeting in 1994? Senator Parer. It was more than one meeting—at least three that I know about. He chaired the meeting in which these matters were discussed and decisions were made. So we do want him to go back, check his records and find out.

It is no use Senator Parer coming in here and saying, `I don't own any shares personally.' The fact is that, if the investment company that runs his trust and the trust own 16 shares that are valuable, and they depend on the fortunes of the coal industry and he is the minister directly responsible for export controls on the coal industry, for diesel fuel rebates and all of these other things that impact there, an allegation could then be made of a potential conflict of interest. So as to avoid those allegations the Prime Minister has properly ruled that, if you own shares either directly or by way of a family trust—other than a blind trust, and no-one has argued that this is a blind trust—and if you are going to get what we understand is a very substantial franked dividend out of all this process into the family trust in which you have an interest, and you are making decisions that affect it, the allegation can be there of a potential conflict of interest.

I would never think for a moment that Senator Parer would consciously and directly take a decision affecting the coal industry to directly benefit himself but that is not the point. The whole point is that he should have declared, in some detail in his Senate pecuniary interest form, the details of the holdings in this particular company. So it is no use the other side going on and saying these are absolute smears; these people are accountable. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Anybody who has watched question time since the parliament resumed would have been aware that Senator Bolkus was in the sights of the government for having leaked confidential Federal Court documents. As a result, the Labor Party have engaged in a deliberate besmirching tactic dealing with people who have been dead for decades, the Baillieu family, and with the Natural Heritage Trust. Do we get any apology from them? No. What do they do? They simply move on to the next issue, such as Senator Quirke making a false allegation about a contract that he alleges this government let, only to find it was the previous Labor administration that let the contract. Do we get an apology from the Labor Party? Absolutely not.

speech.para: We had the spectacle of Senator Sherry asking his first question on his return, making some very grubby allegations in relation to the minister and Deloittes. Today, that was completely debunked. Do we get an apology from Senator Sherry? No. We then had the allegation yesterday from Senator Kerry O'Brien from the Labor Party about an employment agency. That was completely debunked today at question time and exposed as untrue and incorrect. Do we get an apology from Senator O'Brien? No.

Today we moved a censure motion with the support of every senator in this place, other than those from the Labor Party, against Senator Bolkus for his most outrageous behaviour in deliberately and knowingly leaking a confidential Federal Court document. He did that deliberately and knowingly. The Senate has quite properly condemned him for that by censuring him. So what does the Labor Party do? They say, `They finally got Bolkus. They nailed him. What do we do? Our little besmirching tactics on the Natural Heritage Trust, bringing in dead people, making accusations against Deloittes about employment agencies and about contracts being let, and the question Senator Quirk asked have all failed. What are we going to do? We will embark upon a deliberate campaign to besmirch Senator Parer as a smokescreen.'

Senator Parer is one of the most honourable people in this place. To his great credit Senator Ray, in his speech, was very careful not to besmirch the character of Senator Parer. Indeed, he made this telling point. If Senator Parer did something that was not within the guidelines it would have been done inadvertently, in sharp contradistinction to the behaviour of Senator Bolkus, who did what he did knowingly, connivingly and with a deliberate intent to put on the public record a confidential court document in breach of the Federal Court rules.

This taking note of answers today and the Labor Party tactic at question time have been designed simply as a smokescreen to try to protect Senator Bolkus. Senator Bolkus cannot and will not be protected from his own actions and activities. He deliberately embarked upon leaking those two pages of that confidential court document. The Labor Party can try as much as they like to besmirch innocent citizens of this country, dead people or companies but there is nothing as rock solid and as proven as the case against Senator Bolkus for deliberately leaking the information he did.

The Labor Party tactic in this matter is so transparent and such a sham. The Labor Party know what they ought to do; that is, remove Senator Bolkus from the frontbench. If Sena tor Bolkus will not move, he ought to be moved. If Mr Beazley is not willing to move him, I am sure the Australian people will ensure that Mr Beazley never becomes Prime Minister, let alone Senator Bolkus becoming the Attorney-General of this country.

talk.start.para: —It is a pity that Senator Parer is not here and that he has not taken the opportunity to defend himself in this debate. With the greatest respect to Senator Parer, he moved more rapidly out of this chamber than I have seen him move at any other time around this building.

speech.para: The issue of the probity and the honourable conduct of government ministers was made an election matter by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself at the last election. He promised the people of Australia that there would be a code of ministerial conduct which would ensure that private and public dealings by responsible ministers in this country were at the highest possible level and he promised that he would hold his ministers to that code.
In his document, the Prime Minister said:

Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.

That is what the Prime Minister has said is required in these circumstances. What is beyond doubt is that there is an interest of a particular sort by Senator Parer in a mining company, and we know that Senator Parer is the Minister for Resources. That would appear to be directly in conflict with what the Prime Minister requires.

As well as that, there are the Senate's own requirements. The Senate requires that, in stating what their interests are, senators should say what their shareholdings in public and private companies, including holding companies, are and should indicate the names of the companies. This goes to the issue of family and business trusts and nominee companies as well. What we have here are quite clear, fundamental requirements to which senators and ministers have to comply. We also have an obligation by the Prime Minister to ensure that ministers hold to those standards.

What are the facts of this debate, as we know them to this point? In my view, we know that in his words in answers to questions at question time Senator Parer was quite careful in what he said. He said, `I have exactly complied with the Prime Minister's requirements.' I do not know, and I am prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt at this stage, whether that means in a technical sense or in a full blown, proper sense. He said as well, `I have personally no shareholding in a mining company.' Again, that may be a very tightly drawn, technical meaning of what he has said compared to what the facts are and it may not meet the intent or the requirement of the provisions.

What we do know now is that the Parer family trust owns 16 shares in QCMM. QCMM wholly owns Advanced Queensland Resources and Mining which operates the Jellinbah Coal Mining Company in the Bowen Basin. Those 16 shares amount to, I understand, about 1.4 per cent of the company; that is, the trust owns about 1.4 per cent of the mining company, which is valued, according to its June 1996 annual report—the last I have a reference to—at $153 million, which is not an insubstantial amount. Therefore, it is proper and reasonable to conclude that the minister has a beneficial interest in QCMM through a family trust. Apart from the interest QCMM has in Advanced Queensland Resources, the operation company of Jellinbah Coal Mining, QCMM also has a 70 per cent interest in Bowen Basin Coal Pty. Ltd. There is a substantial case to answer here.

In addition to that, the ASC records show that on 30 June this year Senator Parer held 44 shares personally in QCMM Group (ESP). There is a substantial case for the minister to answer here about how those facts set out in the ASC records and documented in the proper way in the companies commission tally with his allegations that he has properly complied with the ministerial code of conduct and that he has no shares in a mining company. It may not be directly that he does but through his trust. He has to answer those allegations fully and properly. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I do not know why you hate successful people so much on your side of the chamber. As soon as anybody is successful, you find the best way you can to try to smear them in any way possible. When Senator Faulkner stands before this chamber and uses the option of his quietly spoken voice to talk, we know that his heart is not really in it. After a series of questions to Senator Parer, he then had to make the big decision about whether to take note of the answers or not, because no answers given by Senator Parer were likely to raise any issues other than those you have tried to raise by trawling around and conducting this smear campaign you have started today—a tactic you have used on practically every other person you have chosen to vilify, inside or outside the Senate chamber.

speech.para: I think I heard Senator Faulkner say during his speech that he was accusing Senator Parer of using public office for personal gain. I think that was the phrase that he used—using `public office for personal gain'. Talking about using public office for personal gain, how do you measure the personal gain that anyone gets from holding a public office? Is it a monetary gain? Is it some position that they gain after they have held public office? I can think of a couple of examples. Former President Kerry Sibraa: was it personal gain after holding public office when he was given a job by the former government as an ambassador overseas? Neal Blewett, a former member: was that personal gain from holding a public office? Graham Maguire: just an ordinary backbench senator all his life who managed to score a few jobs on some boards when he finished—was that personal gain from holding public office? I would not want to go too far if I were you.

There are a great number and you can name as many as you like but, if you are going to talk about personal gain from holding public office, you had better be careful about where you start and where you stop. Can you remember your defence, only two or three years ago, of a former Prime Minister who had a very considerable involvement in a piggery? Would you have considered that to be personal gain from public office? Probably only a few million but that is neither here not there, just a drop in the ocean for these people. `Personal gain from public office'—former member Wayne Swan would not have had a job of personal gain from the public office that he held before; I am quite sure about that. So when you come in here and start talking about personal gain from public office and when you talk about a senator who has spent his life working in the mining industry—as Senator Parer did, and he is well respected and is someone who has been successful; he did not have to have his job propped up by any factional colleagues—
Senator George Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Campbell, let me tell you that he was not responsible for the loss of a hundred thousand jobs either. Senator Parer was responsible for employing people. He actually created employment and, Senator Campbell, a former Prime Minister accused you of costing this country a hundred thousand jobs. That is something you will always remember, Senator Campbell, and we remember it well because the comment was made by someone from your side.

speech.para: Let us get down to the real issue of why the so-called attack on Senator Parer was made today. As Senator Abetz highlighted, it is a fact that we have had a situation today where one of your colleagues has been censured by this parliament. He has been censured in the House of Representatives and he has been censured in the Senate, where the government does not have a majority. A person cannot be censured unless you get the support of other parties in this chamber, and the only ones who stuck by Senator Bolkus were the Labor Party senators.

Let me tell you that some of those did it very reluctantly. I would not want to name names but, although some of those were sitting on that side of the chamber, when the votes went up—and the vote was 44 to about 26 or 27—I could not help but notice a bit of a wry smile come over the faces of some of Senator Bolkus's so-called colleagues when he was censured by this parliament. So this effort today to try and attack Senator Parer for some alleged mistakes in his register of interests can only be described as a very poor effort to try and protect Senator Bolkus. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator O'Chee and the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, he will move:

speech.para: That the Veterans' Vocational Rehabilitation Scheme, as contained in instrument no. 5 of 1997 made under subsection 115B(1) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, be disallowed.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of matters raised by the committee.
Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—

para.inline: Veteran's Vocational Rehabilitation Scheme, being Instrument No 5 of 1997, made under subsection 115B(1) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986

speech.para: The instrument seeks to assist specified classes of veterans to find employment and to continue in employment.

Clause 1.3 .1 defines a service provider as a person or organisation with which the Commission or the Department has entered into an arrangement to provide services. It would appear from the tenor of the Scheme as a whole that such service providers may well be commercial organisations. However, there is no avenue provided in the terms of the Scheme whereby a person or organisation, which is dissatisfied with the decision to reject its application to be a service provider, may seek a review of that decision.

Clauses 1.4.1 to 1.4.3 permit the Secretary to require a veteran to be examined or assessed, or both, by a service provider, and for that service provider to report to the Secretary, who in turn reports to the Commission. However, there is no provision in the Scheme requiring the service provider to maintain confidentiality of the informa tion it acquires in that process. Since the service providers may be private individuals or companies, it does not appear that they would come within the restrictions of the Privacy Act 1988, with the result that any requirement of confidentiality would have to be included in this Scheme.

Paragraph 1.5.2(b) requires the service provider or the Secretary (if they have prepared a rehabilitation plan) to agree with the veteran on its details. This would appear to be an unenforceable provision as the law cannot force parties to come to an agreement.

Clause 3.2.3 provides that an approved scheme should not normally include particular elements. If a scheme were not to be approved because it contained some such element, it would appear to be impossible for a veteran to succeed in a review of that decision. There are, however, no criteria by which the reviewing body might determine whether the case before it was normal or not.

Clause 4.5.2 gives to the Secretary a discretion to determine whether or not a grant has been applied for a proper purpose. However, Chapter 5, which deals with rights of review, applies only to the review of decisions of the Commission, and hence does not apply to the decision of the Secretary under this clause. There does not appear to be any provision in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 which allows for review of any decisions of the Secretary.
The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.

The correspondence read as follows—
Exemption Order made under s.8G of the Christmas Island Act 1958
2 December 1997
The Hon Mark Vaile MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Exemption Order made under s.8G of the Christmas Island Act 1958 , which exempts two companies from the need to comply with the operations of the Travel Agents Act 1985 (WA) as it applies to Christmas Island. The Committee would appreciate your advice on the following matters.

The Explanatory Statement does not indicate whether these are the only agents operating on the Island and, if this is not the case, whether other agents been arbitrarily excluded from the benefits of the Order.
Clause (2) does not appear to serve any practical purpose as the Order must necessarily have effect until revoked and does not need the clause to say so.

Clause (3) provides that the Minister may not unreasonably withhold consent to the approval of an insurance policy. The Explanatory Statement does not advise whether a decision by the Minister to withhold consent is subject to merits review.

The requirement in Clause (3) for the applicants to deliver the policy to the Minister could cause difficulty if an applicant subsequently wished to claim on a policy. In such circumstances delivery of a copy of the policy would appear to be sufficient.

The Explanatory Statement advises that the Order is a temporary measure only but does not indicate how long the Order will be needed. The Explanatory Statement also notes that the Order must be laid before each House of the Federal Parliament but that it need be gazetted only in the Territory Gazette . It may also be appropriate to also gazette such Orders in the Commonwealth Gazette.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations
and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 2 December 1997 addressed to the Honourable Mark Vaile MP, Minister for Transport and Regional Development concerning the Exemption Order issued under the Travel Agents Act 1985 (WA)(CI)(the Act). I am replying as Mr Vaile executed the Order on my behalf.
The following are the responses to your queries concerning the Order and Explanatory Memorandum.

The two travel agents cited in the Order are the only ones operating in the Territory of Christmas Island. Both are major participants in the Territory's tourism industry and play an important role in the Territory's economy. The Order was made to facilitate their obtaining a licence to operate as travel agents and to enable them to become members of IATA so there was no impediment to their arranging international travel to the Territory.

I take your point that the statement that the Order continues until revoked is redundant. However, this statement was included because paragraph 6(2)(a) of the Act provides that the order may specify the period during which the order shall remain in force. It was not thought appropriate to specify a period in the circumstances.

Paragraph 6(2)(b) of the Act provides that an order may provide that its operation is subject to such conditions as are specified in the order. There is no provision in the Act for merits review of the imposition of conditions under section 6 or an exercise of power in a condition. I have instructed my Department to draft an order varying the Order to provide an opportunity for a merits review in the local court in Christmas Island of the Minister's decision to withhold consent pursuant to Clause 3 of the Order.

As you may be aware, travel agents' licences are issued by the Commercial Tribunal of Western Australia. The tribunal must hold hearings if objections to the issue of a licence are lodged and in certain other cases. Should an applicant be refused a licence or have its licence revoked, the applicant is entitled to appeal to the District Court of Western Australia under Division 4 of Part 11 of the Act.
I agree that copies of insurance policies and premium receipts would suffice if it were considered necessary for these to be delivered to the Minister.

It was not possible to estimate how long the Order should remain in force, hence the statement in clause (2). It was considered preferable to have an open-ended order rather than to have to remake it if permanent arrangements could not be made within a set period.

Section 74A of the Interpretation Act 1984 (WA)(CI) provides that if an applied law requires a person to publish an instrument in the Gazette, the requirement is satisfied if the instrument is published in the WA Government Gazette, the Commonwealth Gazette or the Territory Gazette. It is considered that it is sufficient to publish instruments in these cases in the Territory Gazette. This is readily available to Territory residents, who are the main clients of the travel agents. The gazettals would be of limited interest to persons outside the Territory.
Yours sincerely
ALEX SOMLYAY
Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government
2 December 1997
The Hon Alexander Downer MP
Minister for Foreign Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to Locally Engaged Staff Determination 1997/31, which provides for aspects of medical insurance for locally engaged staff in Kenya.

New subclause 5.32.11(4) appears to limit to six the number of children a locally engaged employee may enrol in the group medical assistance scheme to which that clause refers. This would appear improperly to discriminate against those locally engaged staff who have a large family. The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Australian Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee
Thank you for your letter of 2 December 1997 concerning Locally Engaged Staff Determination 1997/31 which provides for aspects of medical insurance for locally engaged staff in Kenya.

The High Commission in Nairobi originally recommended that the number of children a locally engaged employee may enrol in the group medical assistance scheme be limited to six. This was done to provide the Commonwealth with some protection against fraudulent claims relating to extended families. The number was limited to six because this was the maximum number of children declared for enrolment by any member of the staff at the High Commission.

My Department has reviewed the situation and is satisfied that the High Commission can achieve a reasonable degree of protection against fraudulent claims by ensuring that only those children who are defined as dependants by the providers of the Scheme are enrolled. An amending determination will therefore be issued to remove the subclause which limits the number of children which may be enrolled.
Yours sincerely
Alexander Downer
Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 950 standing in my name for today relating to an order for the production of documents be taken as a formal motion.
—This is not an objection and, whilst the government is not opposing the formality of this proposal, I seek leave to make a short statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —This matter relates to the tabling of legal advice in relation to the NTAB and the operation of section 57 of the constitution. The government has clearly received extensive legal and policy advice in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] . I am informed by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) that he is prepared to admit that this legal advice extends to the correct interpretation of section 57 of the constitution. Indeed, the Attorney has informed me that the government has received legal advice on section 57 on a number of occasions. This is not surprising, given the constant difficulties the government has faced in getting its legislative program, for which it has received a clear mandate from the Australian people, through the Senate.

speech.para: The legal advice to the government is clear. The government's action is clearly disagreeing with some of the Senate's amendments, and laying the bill aside in the House has triggered the first stage of section 57 of the constitution. The government's position has been expressly supported by constitutional legal experts. This includes many expert commentators who do not normally support the government's view. In this regard I draw the Senate's attention to the comments of Professor Cheryl Saunders of Melbourne University's law faculty and George Williams from ANU reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 December 1997. Professor Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] Saunders is quoted in this article as saying:
The literal reading of the Constitution seems to suggest that all you need are amendments to the bill by the Senate and a disagreement by the House.
George Williams has subsequently prepared a research note for the parliament's Information and Research Services which explicitly states:

On 6 December 1997 the House of Representatives indicated it would not agree to many of the Senate's amendments and laid the bill aside. This meets the requirement in section 57 that the bill be passed by the Senate with amendments to which the House of Representatives will not agree.

However, in the opinion of the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, s57 has not been complied with. He argues that `there must be an ongoing unwillingness by the House of Representatives to accept amendments made by the Senate' . . .

This interpretation may, as Evans argues, be supported by `the procedures of both Houses'. However, it is not supported by the text of the Constitution. Evans places too much weight on the words `will not agree' in s.57 to find that it is mandatory that the bill be returned to the Senate after the House of Representatives has rejected the Senate amendments. The Constitution merely requires that the bill be passed by the Senate `with amendments to which the House of Representatives will not agree'. The extra step set out by Evans goes beyond the demands of the Constitution.

The only contrary and very vocal view is that being promulgated by the Clerk of the Senate. The Clerk, despite his undoubted expertise in Senate procedural matters, is not a lawyer, is not a constitutional law expert, and regularly puts forward views which extend the power of the Senate. It is not surprising that the government does not seek to rely upon his interpretation.
The government's expressed intention is to pass the
Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No.2]

. We have, in consultation, developed a fair and balanced compromise of all the interests involved. The coalition does not want to have a double dissolution election on the issue of native title. The content of any legal advice which addresses the operation of section 57, therefore, is really irrelevant to the forthcoming Senate debate. The government, nonetheless, will be opposing this motion in accordance with established principle. The general position is clear: legal advice provided to the government is subject to legal professional privilege.

The Senate is well aware of the position taken by successive governments, whether ALP or coalition, that the Senate should not demand the tabling of documents which attract either public interest immunity or legal professional privilege. Indeed, it is interesting to note the views expressed by Senator Bolkus on the tabling of legal advice when he was sitting on the government benches in relation to the Carmen Lawrence matter. After not tabling documents, which included legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department, Senator Bolkus supported this position by stating:
These documents clearly fall within the accepted boundaries of legal professional privilege and public interest immunity. The Senate has traditionally recognised these claims.
The next day, Senator Bolkus went further, in referring to the return to order passed by the Senate, as follows:

That is why your return to order motion is at best vacuous and at worst blatant hypocrisy. It is a disregard of the accepted principles of practice in this place. It is a disregard of accepted principles of government. You know that but, despite knowing it, you come in here with a wish list that you know any responsible government cannot meet.
The now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Gareth Evans, also commented on the need to respect legal professional privilege. On 28 August 1995, Mr Evans said:

The government simply does not make available government documents which fall within accepted boundaries of legal professional privilege and public interest immunity to the Senate. We certainly will not be doing that to a Senate committee. Nor is it the practice or has it been the practice over the years for any government to make available legal advice from its legal advisers made in the course of the normal decision making process of government, for good practical reasons associated with good government and also as a matter of fundamental principle.
The then Senator Evans went on to say:

. . . we are not prepared, as I have already indicated, to make available legal advice prepared in the ordinary course for the purpose of the development of government policy or the making of specific government decisions. The confidential relationship between the government's legal advisers is an essential part of the business of government.
The claim of legal professional privilege as a basis for not tabling material in the Senate has been used by governments of all persuasions.

Other recent examples include Senator Sherry in his then capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on 1 March 1995 in respect of a motion for documents associated with the granting of woodchipping licences. Similarly, on 23 May 1996, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, refused to provide legal advice on the basis that it was subject to legal professional privilege. Senators will all be aware that successive governments have refused to table legal advice on the basis that it is protected by legal professional privilege. As has previously been acknowledged by the ALP, the availability of this privilege is an essential element of good government. The government, therefore, does not accept that it can be compelled to provide any such advice, if it exists, as referred to in the motion. Consequently, the government opposes the motion.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I must say that, in granting leave for Senator Tambling to make a brief statement, I did not realise that in that brief statement he was going to insult half of Australia. However, he has done that, and I certainly must object to the way in which it was done.

speech.para: I am offended by the reference to the Clerk of the Senate. I do not think that matter needed to have been dragged in here. We certainly have used the Clerk of the Senate's advice, but the important thing about the clerk's advice is that he pointed out that the opinion of Sir Garfield Barwick was the basis for that advice, and the comments of Sir Garfield Barwick stand in this debate. They are very important. Those comments said that, unless the processes of the Senate and the House were followed, a double dissolution and a joint sitting of the House would be based on very shaky ground indeed. Those words of Sir Garfield Barwick cannot be contradicted; they stand in this debate. That is what the government should be taking issue with, not with whether the Clerk of the Senate has entered the debate. He gave the Democrats that advice because it was asked for, and it was very legitimate advice indeed. I really do feel a little offended by the way in which Senator Tambling has given his comment to the Senate.

What the Democrats are trying to do, of course, is to allow the people of Australia to have some part in the spending of their money. If we go to an early election, we will be spending $60 million upfront to have an election which may be based on dubious constitutional grounds if, in fact, the purpose is to pass legislation such as the Wik legislation, which we may then find at a later occasion is struck down by the High Court. That is the gamble we are talking about; it is a gamble about opinions. We do not believe that it is worth taking that gamble when, in fact, the Senate and all the people of Australia—all of us—could have a look at the opinions upon which the government is relying.

We accept that the government received legal opinion. What we are not sure about still is whether or not the government sought and received independent legal opinion before its action in December in laying aside the bill. We hear what you are saying. We are not going to contradict that. Obviously you sought legal opinion. But the question still remains as to whether or not you sought independent legal opinion before the bill was laid aside. That question still remains an open question. For those reasons, I have asked that general business notice of motion No. 950 be taken as a formal motion and we will see where we go.
